protocols.name: Traumatic Brain Injury Management

Applicability Gate: • Documented suspected or confirmed traumatic brain injury
• Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) assessed after adequate cardiopulmonary resuscitation
Trigger Criteria (Exact): • Presence of suspected or confirmed traumatic brain injury with documented post-resuscitation GCS
Severity Classification (Non-Triggering): • Mild traumatic brain injury: GCS 13–15 after resuscitation
• Moderate traumatic brain injury: GCS 9–12 after resuscitation
• Severe traumatic brain injury: GCS 3–8 after resuscitation
Required Data Elements: • Documented Glasgow Coma Scale score
• Documentation confirming GCS assessed after adequate cardiopulmonary resuscitation
• Location and timing of GCS assessment (e.g., Emergency Department)
Timing-Critical Elements: • GCS must reflect post-resuscitation neurologic status
• GCS assessment must occur during initial Emergency Department evaluation or equivalent documented assessment
Failure Behavior: • INDETERMINATE if post-resuscitation GCS is not documented
• INDETERMINATE if timing of GCS assessment relative to resuscitation is unclear
Not Evaluated When: • No documented suspected or confirmed head injury
• GCS assessment performed prior to adequate cardiopulmonary resuscitation
Optional Missing-Data Hint: • Emergency Department documentation explicitly stating post-resuscitation GCS score and timing
Decision Flow (Authoritative Execution L: Does the patient meet Applicability Gate?

protocols.name: Rib Fracture Management

Applicability Gate: • Documented rib fracture(s) confirmed on imaging
Trigger Pathway B: • Three or more total rib fractures
• At least two of the following physiologic findings:
– Poor cough or poor secretion clearance
Required Data Elements: • Imaging confirming rib fracture location and rib numbers
• Patient age
• Respiratory rate
• Incentive spirometry measurement
• Pain assessment documentation
• Nursing or respiratory therapy documentation of cough and secretion clearance
Timing-Critical Elements: • Trigger evaluation based on admission status
• Timing references are evaluative only and must not be treated as prescriptive
Failure Behavior: • INDETERMINATE if rib fracture numbering is unclear
• INDETERMINATE if required physiologic or pain data are missing
Not Evaluated When: • Ongoing shock or active resuscitation
• Fractures limited to ribs 1, 2, 11, or 12
• Sepsis
• Severe traumatic brain injury
• Documented anatomic or clinical contraindications where risk outweighs benefit
Optional Missing-Data Hint: • Trauma Surgeon documentation regarding pain control and secretion clearance
Decision Flow (Authoritative Execution L: Does the patient meet Applicability Gate?
Does patient meet Trigger Pathway A or Trigger Pathway B and age constraint?

protocols.raw_block:
PROTOCOL: Rib Fracture Management

Protocol Class:
CLASS I — Triggerable Protocol

Applicability Gate:
• Documented rib fracture(s) confirmed on imaging

Trigger Criteria (Exact):
Trigger Pathway A:
• Flail chest involving ribs 3 through 10

OR

Trigger Pathway B:
• Fractures involving ribs 3 through 10
AND
• Three or more total rib fractures
AND
• At least two of the following physiologic findings:
  – Respiratory rate > 20
  – Incentive spirometry < 50% predicted
  – Uncontrolled pain
  – Poor cough or poor secretion clearance

Additional Trigger Constraints:
• Patient age ≥ 18 years

Required Data Elements:
• Imaging confirming rib fracture location and rib numbers
• Patient age
• Respiratory rate
• Incentive spirometry measurement
• Pain assessment documentation
• Nursing or respiratory therapy documentation of cough and secretion clearance

Authoritative Sources:
• Trauma H&P
• Physician notes
• Nursing documentation
• Imaging reports
• Respiratory therapy documentation

Timing-Critical Elements:
• Trigger evaluation based on admission status
• Timing references are evaluative only and must not be treated as prescriptive

Failure Behavior:
• INDETERMINATE if rib fracture numbering is unclear
• INDETERMINATE if required physiologic or pain data are missing

Not Evaluated When:
• Ongoing shock or active resuscitation
• Fractures limited to ribs 1, 2, 11, or 12
• Sepsis
• Severe traumatic brain injury
• Documented anatomic or clinical contraindications where risk outweighs benefit

Optional Missing-Data Hint:
• Imaging report specifying rib numbers
• Incentive spirometry percent predicted
• Trauma Surgeon documentation regarding pain control and secretion clearance

Is required trigger data present?

Does patient meet Trigger Pathway A or Trigger Pathway B and age constraint?

• NO → NOT TRIGGERED

protocols.name: Blunt Abdominal Trauma

Applicability Gate: • Suspected or confirmed blunt mechanism involving the abdomen
Trigger Criteria (Exact): • Hemodynamic instability defined as at least two of the following:
– Systolic blood pressure < 90 mmHg on more than one documented reading
AND at least one of: • Diffuse peritoneal irritation on physical examination
• Hemorrhagic shock with documented concern for intra-abdominal blood loss
• Positive FAST examination in a hemodynamically unstable patient
Trigger Pathway B — Imaging-Based Abdominal Injury:
• Abdominal CT imaging demonstrating traumatic abdominal injury
Required Data Elements: • Blood pressure measurements (with repeat readings if < 90 mmHg)
• Heart rate
• Respiratory rate
• Abdominal physical examination findings
• FAST examination result (if performed)
• Hemodynamic status at time of FAST or imaging
• Abdominal CT imaging report (if obtained)
Timing-Critical Elements: • Hemodynamic status assessed contemporaneously with abdominal evaluation
• FAST timing relative to documented vital signs
• Timing references are evaluative only and must not be treated as prescriptive
Failure Behavior: • INDETERMINATE if required vital sign data are missing or incomplete
• INDETERMINATE if FAST result is undocumented when FAST is referenced
• INDETERMINATE if imaging findings are referenced but imaging report is unavailable
Not Evaluated When: • No blunt mechanism involving the abdomen
• Isolated penetrating abdominal trauma (handled under separate protocol)
Optional Missing-Data Hint: • Repeat vital sign documentation clarifying hemodynamic status
Decision Flow (Authoritative Execution L: Does the patient meet Applicability Gate?
Does patient meet Trigger Pathway A or Trigger Pathway B?

protocols.raw_block:
PROTOCOL: Blunt Abdominal Trauma

Protocol Class:
CLASS I — Triggerable Protocol

Applicability Gate:
• Suspected or confirmed blunt mechanism involving the abdomen

Trigger Criteria (Exact):

Trigger Pathway A — Hemodynamic Instability:
• Hemodynamic instability defined as at least two of the following:
  – Systolic blood pressure < 90 mmHg on more than one documented reading
  – Heart rate > 100 beats per minute
  – Respiratory rate > 30 breaths per minute

AND at least one of:
• Diffuse peritoneal irritation on physical examination
• Hemorrhagic shock with documented concern for intra-abdominal blood loss
• Positive FAST examination in a hemodynamically unstable patient

OR

Trigger Pathway B — Imaging-Based Abdominal Injury:
• Ruptured diaphragm
• Free intraperitoneal air
• Retroperitoneal air
• Abdominal CT imaging demonstrating traumatic abdominal injury

Required Data Elements:
• Blood pressure measurements (with repeat readings if < 90 mmHg)
• Heart rate
• Respiratory rate
• Abdominal physical examination findings
• FAST examination result (if performed)
• Hemodynamic status at time of FAST or imaging

• No blunt mechanism involving the abdomen

protocols.name: Blunt Chest Trauma

Applicability Gate: • Suspected or confirmed blunt mechanism involving the thorax
At least one of the following documented: • Documented concern for cardiac contusion WITH:
• Documented concern for tracheobronchial injury with supporting imaging or bronchoscopy
• Documented concern for thoracic aortic injury with supporting imaging
• Documented concern for esophageal injury with supporting imaging or diagnostic evaluation
• Simple pneumothorax (plain chest x-ray or occult pneumothorax on CT)
Required Data Elements: • Documentation of blunt thoracic mechanism
• Chest imaging report (portable chest x-ray and/or CT chest)
• Vital signs and hemodynamic status
• FAST examination result when cardiac tamponade is referenced
• EKG report when cardiac contusion or severe anterior chest trauma is referenced
• Documentation of respiratory findings when chest wall injury is referenced
Timing-Critical Elements: • Timing references are evaluative only
• Chest imaging timing relative to admission must be documented when referenced
• FAST or EKG timing must be documented when those findings are referenced
Failure Behavior: • INDETERMINATE if a referenced diagnostic finding lacks supporting documentation
• INDETERMINATE if hemodynamic status at time of referenced evaluation is unclear
Not Evaluated When: • No blunt mechanism involving the thorax
• Isolated penetrating chest trauma (handled under separate protocol)
Optional Missing-Data Hint: • FAST or EKG report when referenced
Decision Flow (Authoritative Execution L: Does the patient meet Applicability Gate?
Is required trigger data present for any referenced criterion?
Does patient meet at least one trigger criterion?

protocols.name: Penetrating Abdominal Trauma

Protocol Class: • Patient with penetrating mechanism with potential trajectory involving the peritoneal cavity or retroperitoneum
• Entry wound located between the fourth intercostal space and the perineum
At least one of the following documented: • Active, uncontrolled hemorrhage from the penetrating wound
• Peritoneal signs documented on physical examination
• Hemodynamic instability with documented positive FAST examination
• Thoracoabdominal penetrating wound with positive FAST (pericardial and/or abdominal)
• Anterior penetrating abdominal wound with documented violation of anterior abdominal fascia
• Posterior or flank penetrating wound with CT evidence of retroperitoneal organ injury
• Mechanism of injury and wound location
• Physical examination documenting peritoneal signs or evisceration (if present)
• Vital signs sufficient to determine hemodynamic stability
• FAST examination result and timing (if performed)
• Documentation of wound exploration findings for anterior abdominal wounds
• Hemodynamic status documented contemporaneously with FAST examination
• Operative decision-making timing documented when emergent criteria are met
• CT imaging obtained only in hemodynamically stable patients, when performed
• INDETERMINATE if hemodynamic status cannot be determined from documentation
• INDETERMINATE if FAST examination is indicated but result is not documented
• INDETERMINATE if wound depth or fascial penetration cannot be determined from documentation
• NOT TRIGGERED if no documented evidence of peritoneal or retroperitoneal violation exists
• No penetrating mechanism involving the abdomen is documented
• Injuries isolated to thorax or neck without documented abdominal trajectory
• Explicit documentation of wound exploration findings
• FAST examination result with timestamp relative to documented instability
Does the patient meet Applicability Gate?
Does the patient meet at least one trigger criterion?

protocols.name: Penetrating Neck Injury

Protocol Class: • Patient with penetrating injury to the neck, defined as penetration of the skin within the circumferential region bounded by the clavicles inferiorly and the base of the skull superiorly
• Excludes injuries limited to the oral cavity or pharyngeal mucosa without external neck penetration
At least one of the following documented: • Hemodynamic shock attributable to neck injury
• Active external hemorrhage from the neck wound
• Obvious tracheal injury documented on exam or procedure
• Platysma violation with injury classified as Zone I, Zone II, or Zone III
• Physical examination documenting hemorrhage, hematoma, airway compromise, or tracheal injury (if present)
• Anatomic zone classification (Zone I, II, or III) when platysma is violated
• Vital signs sufficient to determine presence or absence of shock
• Imaging reports (e.g., chest x-ray, CT angiography, esophagram when obtained)
• Immediate operative intervention required when shock, active hemorrhage, expanding hematoma, airway compromise, or obvious tracheal injury is documented
• Zone-directed diagnostic studies performed only after documented platysma violation, when applicable
• INDETERMINATE if platysma integrity cannot be determined from documentation
• INDETERMINATE if shock status or airway status is unclear
• NOT TRIGGERED if platysma is intact and no emergent trigger criteria are documented
• Penetrating injuries limited to the oral or pharyngeal mucosa without external neck penetration
• Superficial neck wounds with documented intact platysma and no concerning clinical findings
• Clear anatomic zone classification in provider notes
Does the patient meet Applicability Gate?
Does the patient meet at least one trigger criterion?

protocols.name: Peripheral Vascular Trauma

Protocol Class: • Patient with extremity trauma (blunt or penetrating)
• Documentation raises concern for possible vascular injury to an extremity
At least one of the following documented: A) Hard signs of arterial injury
• Clinical signs of limb ischemia (e.g., pallor, pain, paralysis, paresthesia, poikilothermia)
B) Soft signs of arterial injury
• Injury in proximity to a major named vascular structure
• Hypotension or moderate blood loss temporally associated with extremity injury
• Fracture associated with evidence of poor arterial perfusion
• Posterior knee dislocation or anterior elbow dislocation (including spontaneously reduced)
• Penetrating extremity wound with trajectory near a major artery AND at least one hard or soft sign present
• Mechanism and anatomic location of extremity injury
• Vascular examination findings (palpation or Doppler pulses, bruit, thrill)
• Documentation of hemorrhage or ischemic findings when present
• Neurologic examination identifying major nerve deficits
• Imaging results (CT angiography or formal arteriography if obtained)
• Doppler or ankle-brachial index (ABI) results when performed
• Vascular examination performed during initial trauma evaluation
• Imaging obtained promptly when hard or soft signs are documented
• Presence of palpable distal pulses does not exclude arterial injury
• INDETERMINATE if vascular examination findings are not documented
• INDETERMINATE if injury proximity or neurologic findings cannot be determined
• NOT TRIGGERED if no hard or soft signs of arterial injury are documented
• Isolated musculoskeletal injury with no documented concern for vascular compromise
• Imaging report explicitly addressing arterial integrity
Does the patient meet Applicability Gate?
Does the patient meet at least one trigger criterion?

protocols.raw_block:
PROTOCOL: Peripheral Vascular Trauma

Protocol Class:
CLASS I — Triggerable Protocol

⸻

Applicability Gate

• Patient with extremity trauma (blunt or penetrating)
• Documentation raises concern for possible vascular injury to an extremity

⸻

Trigger Criteria (Exact)

At least one of the following documented findings:

A) Hard signs of arterial injury
• Absent distal pulses
• Audible bruit or palpable thrill
• Active or pulsatile hemorrhage
• Clinical signs of limb ischemia (e.g., pallor, pain, paralysis, paresthesia, poikilothermia)

OR

B) Soft signs of arterial injury
• Injury in proximity to a major named vascular structure
• Major single nerve deficit involving:
– Sciatic
– Femoral
– Median
– Ulnar
– Radial
• Non-expanding hematoma
• Reduced or asymmetric distal pulses
• Hypotension or moderate blood loss temporally associated with extremity injury
• Fracture associated with evidence of poor arterial perfusion
• Posterior knee dislocation or anterior elbow dislocation (including spontaneously reduced)
• Penetrating extremity wound with trajectory near a major artery AND at least one hard or soft sign present

⸻

Required Data Elements

• Mechanism and anatomic location of extremity injury
• Vascular examination findings (palpation or Doppler pulses, bruit, thrill)
• Documentation of hemorrhage or ischemic findings when present
• Neurologic examination identifying major nerve deficits
• Imaging results (CT angiography or formal arteriography if obtained)
• Doppler or ankle-brachial index (ABI) results when performed

⸻

Authoritative Sources

• Trauma H&P
• Physician notes
• Nursing documentation
• Imaging reports
• Vascular studies (CTA, arteriogram, Doppler/ABI)

⸻

Timing-Critical Elements

• Vascular examination performed during initial trauma evaluation
• Imaging obtained promptly when hard or soft signs are documented
• Presence of palpable distal pulses does not exclude arterial injury

⸻

Failure Behavior

• INDETERMINATE if vascular examination findings are not documented
• INDETERMINATE if injury proximity or neurologic findings cannot be determined
• NOT TRIGGERED if no hard or soft signs of arterial injury are documented

⸻

Not Evaluated When

• No extremity trauma
• Isolated musculoskeletal injury with no documented concern for vascular compromise

⸻

Optional Missing-Data Hint

• Documented pulse examination (palpation or Doppler)
• ABI measurement
• Imaging report explicitly addressing arterial integrity

protocols.name: Blunt Cerebrovascular Injury (BCVI)

Protocol Class: • Mechanism raises potential involvement of cervical or cerebrovascular structures
At least one of the following documented: • Arterial hemorrhage from the neck, mouth, or ear
• Cervical bruit in a patient < 50 years of age
• Neurologic deficit inconsistent with head CT findings
• Ischemic stroke identified on CT or MRI
• Mechanism compatible with cervical hyperextension, hyperflexion, or rotation
• Basilar skull fracture involving the carotid canal
• Closed head injury consistent with diffuse axonal injury with GCS < 6
• Cervical transverse foramen fracture, subluxation, or ligamentous injury at any level
• Any cervical spine fracture involving C1–C3
• Clothesline-type injury or seatbelt abrasion with significant cervical pain, swelling, or altered mental status
• Upper rib fractures involving rib 1 and/or rib 2
• Facial and skull base imaging results
• Documentation of hemorrhage, hematoma, or bruit when present
• Imaging reports (CT head, CT cervical spine, CT angiography neck, MRI)
• Cervical CTA performed when any trigger criterion is documented
• CTA neck automatically included when ordered per institutional trauma imaging pathway:
– Category I trauma patients receiving contrast CT
– Category II trauma patients activated prior to CT with contrast imaging ordered
(Note: pathway inclusion does not override trigger logic; it satisfies imaging acquisition only.)
• INDETERMINATE if neurologic examination is not documented
• INDETERMINATE if mechanism or cervical imaging findings are unclear
• NOT TRIGGERED if no clinical signs or screening risk factors are documented
• Isolated penetrating cerebrovascular injuries (managed under separate protocol)
Does the patient meet Applicability Gate?
Does the patient meet at least one trigger criterion?

protocols.raw_block:
PROTOCOL: Blunt Cerebrovascular Injury (BCVI)

Protocol Class:
CLASS I — Triggerable Protocol

⸻

Applicability Gate

• Patient with blunt trauma
• Mechanism raises potential involvement of cervical or cerebrovascular structures

⸻

Trigger Criteria (Exact)

At least one of the following documented findings:

⸻

A) Clinical Signs (Any)
• Arterial hemorrhage from the neck, mouth, or ear
• Expanding cervical hematoma
• Cervical bruit in a patient < 50 years of age
• Focal or lateralizing neurologic deficit
• Neurologic deficit inconsistent with head CT findings
• Ischemic stroke identified on CT or MRI

⸻

B) Screening Risk Factors (Any)
• Mechanism compatible with cervical hyperextension, hyperflexion, or rotation
• Severe facial trauma
• Basilar skull fracture involving the carotid canal
• Closed head injury consistent with diffuse axonal injury with GCS < 6
• Cervical transverse foramen fracture, subluxation, or ligamentous injury at any level
• Any cervical spine fracture involving C1–C3
• Clothesline-type injury or seatbelt abrasion with significant cervical pain, swelling, or altered mental status
• Upper rib fractures involving rib 1 and/or rib 2
• Near-hanging with anoxic brain injury

⸻

Required Data Elements

• Mechanism of injury
• Neurologic examination findings
• GCS score when applicable
• Cervical spine imaging results
• Facial and skull base imaging results
• Documentation of hemorrhage, hematoma, or bruit when present

• Cervical CTA performed when any trigger criterion is documented

– Category I trauma patients receiving contrast CT
– Category II trauma patients activated prior to CT with contrast imaging ordered

(Note: pathway inclusion does not override trigger logic; it satisfies imaging acquisition only.)

⸻

• INDETERMINATE if neurologic examination is not documented
• INDETERMINATE if mechanism or cervical imaging findings are unclear
• NOT TRIGGERED if no clinical signs or screening risk factors are documented

⸻

• Isolated penetrating cerebrovascular injuries (managed under separate protocol)

⸻

protocols.raw_block:
PROTOCOL: DVT Prophylaxis – Adult Trauma Patient

Protocol Class:
CLASS I — Triggerable Protocol

⸻

Applicability Gate (Hard Gate)

This protocol applies to ALL trauma patients meeting ALL of the following:

• Age ≥ 16 years
• Trauma admission
• Hospital length of stay ≥ 24 hours

If ANY applicability element is missing → INDETERMINATE
No exclusions are inferred.

⸻

Trigger Expectation (Governance Position)

Chemical DVT prophylaxis is EXPECTED for all applicable patients unless a documented contraindication exists.

The system does NOT decide appropriateness.
It only evaluates documentation, timing, and contraindication logic.

⸻

Trigger Criteria (Exact)

The protocol is TRIGGERED for all applicable patients unless one or more documented contraindications are present.

Contraindications must be explicitly documented and include:

• Active bleeding
• Uncorrected coagulopathy
• Ongoing anticoagulation at admission not reversed
• Planned operative intervention within 24 hours (temporary hold only)
• Intracranial hemorrhage → Parkland Protocol governs timing
• Ambulatory status MAY be documented but does NOT auto-exclude

⸻

Required Data Elements

• Patient age
• Admission date/time
• Hospital LOS ≥ 24 hours
• Injury pattern
• Active bleeding status
• Coagulation status
• Operative plans within 24 hours
• Ambulatory status (BMAT)
• Presence/absence of intracranial hemorrhage
• If ICH present → Parkland risk tier documentation
• DVT prophylaxis order status and timing

⸻

Authoritative Sources

• Trauma H&P
• Physician notes
• Nursing documentation
• Operative notes
• Imaging reports
• Laboratory data
• Neurosurgical documentation (if ICH present)

⸻

Timing-Critical Elements

• Chemical DVT prophylaxis should be initiated within 24 hours of arrival unless contraindicated
• If surgery occurs within 24 hours → initiate within 24 hours post-op
• Solid organ injury → initiate once hemoglobin stabilizes
• Spinal cord injury → initiate within 72 hours
• Intracranial hemorrhage → Parkland Protocol timing ONLY

⸻

Failure Behavior

• INDETERMINATE if contraindication status cannot be determined
• INDETERMINATE if timing of prophylaxis cannot be determined
• INDETERMINATE if Parkland risk tier is required but not documented
• NOT TRIGGERED is NOT permitted solely due to ambulation or short stay unless explicitly documented and justified

⸻

Not Evaluated When

• Age < 16
• Non-trauma admission
• Hospital LOS < 24 hours

⸻

Optional Missing-Data Hints

• Explicit contraindication documentation
• Timing of prophylaxis orders
• Neurosurgical Parkland classification

⸻

🧠 PARKLAND PROTOCOL — EXECUTABLE DECISION FLOW

Applies to: ALL patients with intracranial hemorrhage

⸻

START

Does the patient have traumatic brain injury (TBI)?
• NO → Return to standard DVT timing
• YES → Continue

Craniectomy or ICP monitor present?
• YES → HIGH RISK TBI
 → Discuss initiation with Neurosurgery
 → Initiate chemical prophylaxis when imaging stable AND ICP monitor removed
 → Consider IVC filter if anticoagulation contraindicated
• NO → Continue

Does patient meet ANY Modified Berne-Norwood Criteria?
• SDH > 8 mm
• EDH > 8 mm
• Contusion or intraventricular hemorrhage > 2 cm
• Multiple contusions per lobe

• YES → MODERATE RISK TBI
 → Repeat CT at 72 hours post-injury
 → If stable → Initiate Enoxaparin at 72 hours
 → If worsened → Treat as HIGH RISK
• NO → Continue

Tiny isolated SAH with GCS 15?
• YES → LOW RISK TBI
 → No repeat CT required
 → Initiate Enoxaparin at 24 hours post-injury
• NO → Continue

Repeat CT at 24 hours shows worsening?
• YES → MODERATE RISK TBI
• NO → LOW RISK TBI

⸻

Parkland Enforcement Notes

• Parkland Protocol is the ONLY determinant for DVT timing in ICH
• The system must not infer neurosurgical clearance
• Missing Parkland tier → INDETERMINATE

⸻

✅ Decision Flow (Top-Level Protocol Logic)

START

Does patient meet Applicability Gate?
• NO → STOP (Not Evaluated)
• YES → Continue

Is required data present?
• NO → INDETERMINATE
• YES → Continue

Is chemical DVT prophylaxis contraindicated?
• YES → TRIGGERED (Contraindicated — documented)
• NO → Continue

Was chemical DVT prophylaxis ordered within required timeframe?
• YES → TRIGGERED
• NO → TRIGGERED (Delayed / Absent — requires review)

PROTOCOL: Geriatric Trauma Guideline

Protocol Class:
CLASS I — Triggerable Protocol

⸻

Applicability Gate (Hard Gate)

This protocol applies to ALL trauma patients meeting ALL of the following:

• Trauma admission
• Age ≥ 65 years

If age is not documented → INDETERMINATE

⸻

Trigger Criteria (Exact)

The protocol is TRIGGERED when the patient meets BOTH:

⸻

A) Qualifying Injury (At least ONE):
• Subdural hematoma or epidural hematoma
• > 3 rib fractures
• Pulmonary contusion, pneumothorax, or hemothorax
• Blunt cardiac injury
• Pelvic fracture
• Long bone fracture
• Spinal fracture with or without neurologic deficit

Exclusions (do NOT qualify alone):
• Isolated spinous process fractures
• Isolated thoracic or lumbar transverse process fractures

⸻

B) Qualifying Medical Vulnerability (At least ONE):
• GFR < 45 mL/min/1.73m²
• On anticoagulant therapy (excluding aspirin)
• Arrhythmia or ejection fraction ≤ 40%
• Cirrhosis
• Alcohol dependence
• Baseline home oxygen use
• BMI ≥ 50
• Diabetes mellitus
• Syncope

• Patient age
• Injury diagnoses with imaging confirmation
• Rib fracture count (if present)
• Renal function (GFR)

PROTOCOL: Emergency Resuscitative Thoracotomy

Protocol Class:
CLASS I — Triggerable Protocol

⸻

Applicability Gate (Hard Gate)

If trauma status or pulselessness is not documented → INDETERMINATE

⸻

Definitions (Binding)

Signs of Life include ANY of the following:
• Organized cardiac electrical activity
• Measurable blood pressure
• Respiratory effort
• Pupillary response
• Purposeful movement

⸻

Trigger Criteria (Exact)

The protocol is TRIGGERED when ANY of the following are met:

Penetrating Trauma
• Pulseless patient with penetrating thoracic injury, with OR without signs of life, AND
• Arrest is witnessed or immediately preceded by signs of life

• Pulseless patient with penetrating extrathoracic injury, with signs of life

Blunt Trauma
• Pulseless patient with blunt trauma AND signs of life present

⸻

Required Data Elements

• Mechanism of injury (penetrating thoracic, penetrating extrathoracic, blunt)
• Presence or absence of pulse
• Presence or absence of signs of life (as defined above)
• Timing of arrest relative to arrival and resuscitation
• Documentation of witnessed arrest or immediate pre-arrest signs of life

⸻

Authoritative Sources

• Trauma H&P
• Physician notes
• Nursing documentation
• EMS documentation
• Monitor data (cardiac electrical activity)
• Operative notes

⸻

Timing-Critical Elements

• Determination of pulselessness and signs of life at presentation or during resuscitation
• Decision-making occurs immediately upon meeting criteria
• Procedure performed concurrently with ongoing resuscitative efforts

⸻

Failure Behavior

• INDETERMINATE if signs of life cannot be determined
• INDETERMINATE if mechanism of injury is unclear
• INDETERMINATE if arrest timing or downtime is not documented
• NOT TRIGGERED if patient is not pulseless

⸻

Not Evaluated When

• Non-trauma cardiac arrest
• Sustained spontaneous circulation
• Prolonged unwitnessed arrest without documented signs of life

⸻

Optional Missing-Data Hints

• EMS documentation of arrest timing
• Monitor strips showing organized electrical activity
• Explicit documentation of signs of life prior to arrest

⸻

START

Does the patient meet Applicability Gate (trauma + pulseless)?

protocols.name: Traumatic Arrest

This protocol applies ONLY when ALL of t: • Patient is in cardiac arrest (absence of palpable pulse)
• Evaluation occurs during active resuscitation in the Emergency Department
If trauma status or arrest status is unclear → INDETERMINATE
Cardiac arrest resulting from a traumatic mechanism, not primary medical etiology.
The protocol is TRIGGERED when ANY of th: • Traumatic cardiac arrest with signs of life present at the scene, en route, or on arrival
• Traumatic cardiac arrest without signs of life, requiring immediate trauma-directed resuscitation
• Confirmation of cardiac arrest (absence of pulse)
• Presence or absence of signs of life (as defined above)
• Timing of arrest relative to arrival and resuscitation
• Immediate determination of traumatic arrest and signs of life
• Rapid primary survey performed during arrest
• Early trauma-directed interventions (airway, bilateral pleural decompression, hemorrhage control)
• INDETERMINATE if signs of life cannot be determined
• INDETERMINATE if traumatic vs medical etiology cannot be determined
• NOT TRIGGERED if patient is not in cardiac arrest
• Trauma patient with sustained spontaneous circulation
• This protocol does not determine procedural eligibility
• Evaluation for Emergency Resuscitative Thoracotomy is governed exclusively by the Emergency Resuscitative Thoracotomy protocol
• Termination of resuscitation decisions are clinical actions, not trigger criteria
• EMS documentation of arrest timing and signs of life

If trauma status or arrest status is unclear → INDETERMINATE

⸻

Definitions (Binding)

Traumatic Cardiac Arrest
Cardiac arrest resulting from a traumatic mechanism, not primary medical etiology.

Signs of Life include ANY of the following:
• Organized cardiac electrical activity
• Measurable blood pressure
• Respiratory effort
• Pupillary response
• Purposeful movement

⸻

Trigger Criteria (Exact)

The protocol is TRIGGERED when ANY of the following are present:

• Traumatic cardiac arrest with signs of life present at the scene, en route, or on arrival
• Traumatic cardiac arrest without signs of life, requiring immediate trauma-directed resuscitation

⸻

Required Data Elements

• Mechanism of injury (blunt vs penetrating)
• Confirmation of cardiac arrest (absence of pulse)
• Presence or absence of signs of life (as defined above)
• Cardiac rhythm and monitor data
• Documentation of trauma-directed resuscitative interventions
• FAST examination results (if performed)
• Timing of arrest relative to arrival and resuscitation

⸻

Authoritative Sources

• Trauma H&P
• Physician notes
• Nursing documentation
• EMS documentation
• Monitor data (EKG)
• Point-of-care ultrasound documentation
• Operative notes (if applicable)

⸻

Timing-Critical Elements

• Immediate determination of traumatic arrest and signs of life
• Rapid primary survey performed during arrest
• Early trauma-directed interventions (airway, bilateral pleural decompression, hemorrhage control)
• Blood product resuscitation initiated promptly

⸻

Failure Behavior

• INDETERMINATE if signs of life cannot be determined
• INDETERMINATE if traumatic vs medical etiology cannot be determined
• NOT TRIGGERED if patient is not in cardiac arrest

⸻

Not Evaluated When

• Non-traumatic cardiac arrest
• Trauma patient with sustained spontaneous circulation

⸻

Relationship to Other Protocols (Binding Clarification)

• This protocol does not determine procedural eligibility
• Evaluation for Emergency Resuscitative Thoracotomy is governed exclusively by the Emergency Resuscitative Thoracotomy protocol
• Termination of resuscitation decisions are clinical actions, not trigger criteria

⸻

Optional Missing-Data Hints

• EMS documentation of arrest timing and signs of life
• Monitor strips documenting electrical activity
• FAST documentation during arrest

⸻

Decision Flow (Authoritative Execution Logic)

START

Does the patient meet Applicability Gate (trauma + cardiac arrest)?
• NO → STOP (Not Evaluated)
• YES → Continue

Is required trigger data present?
• NO → INDETERMINATE
• YES → Continue

Is this a traumatic cardiac arrest requiring trauma-directed resuscitation?
• YES → TRIGGERED
• NO → NOT TRIGGERED

protocols.name: Management and Triage of Burned Patients

Protocol Class: • Patient with thermal injury consistent with burn
At least one of the following American B: • Partial thickness burns > 10% total body surface area (TBSA)
• Burns involving face, hands, feet, genitalia, perineum, or major joints
• Third degree (full thickness) burns of any size
• Burn injury in patients with pre-existing medical disorders that could complicate management, prolong recovery, or affect mortality
• Burns with concomitant trauma (e.g., fractures) when the burn poses the greatest risk of morbidity or mortality
• Pediatric burn patients requiring a burn center verified to treat children
• Burn injury in patients requiring special social, emotional, or rehabilitative intervention
• Burn depth classification (partial vs full thickness)
• Estimated total body surface area (TBSA) burned
• Presence of inhalation injury or carbon monoxide exposure
• Pre-existing medical conditions impacting burn care
• TBSA and burn depth assessment during initial evaluation
• Trauma Surgeon evaluation prior to transfer for patients with > 20% TBSA burn and suspicion for concomitant injuries
• Early airway assessment when inhalation injury is suspected
• Early initiation of burn resuscitation and transfer coordination
• INDETERMINATE if TBSA cannot be estimated
• INDETERMINATE if burn depth or involved body regions are unclear
• NOT TRIGGERED if burn does not meet any ABA referral criteria
• Non-injury thermal exposure without tissue injury
• Clear identification of involved anatomic regions
Does the patient meet Applicability Gate?

protocols.raw_block:
PROTOCOL: Management and Triage of Burned Patients

Protocol Class:
CLASS I — Triggerable Protocol

⸻

Applicability Gate

• Patient with thermal injury consistent with burn
• Applies to all ages

⸻

Trigger Criteria (Exact)

At least one of the following American Burn Association (ABA) referral criteria:

• Partial thickness burns > 10% total body surface area (TBSA)
• Burns involving face, hands, feet, genitalia, perineum, or major joints
• Third degree (full thickness) burns of any size
• Electrical burns, including lightning injury
• Chemical burns
• Inhalation injury
• Burn injury in patients with pre-existing medical disorders that could complicate management, prolong recovery, or affect mortality
• Burns with concomitant trauma (e.g., fractures) when the burn poses the greatest risk of morbidity or mortality
• Pediatric burn patients requiring a burn center verified to treat children
• Burn injury in patients requiring special social, emotional, or rehabilitative intervention

⸻

Required Data Elements

• Burn mechanism (thermal, electrical, chemical, inhalation)
• Burn depth classification (partial vs full thickness)
• Estimated total body surface area (TBSA) burned
• Anatomic locations involved
• Patient age
• Presence of concomitant traumatic injuries
• Presence of inhalation injury or carbon monoxide exposure
• Pre-existing medical conditions impacting burn care

⸻

Authoritative Sources

• Trauma H&P
• Physician notes
• Nursing documentation
• EMS documentation
• Imaging reports
• Laboratory data (including carboxyhemoglobin when indicated)

⸻

Timing-Critical Elements

• TBSA and burn depth assessment during initial evaluation
• Trauma Surgeon evaluation prior to transfer for patients with > 20% TBSA burn and suspicion for concomitant injuries
• Early airway assessment when inhalation injury is suspected
• Early initiation of burn resuscitation and transfer coordination

⸻

Failure Behavior

• INDETERMINATE if TBSA cannot be estimated
• INDETERMINATE if burn depth or involved body regions are unclear
• NOT TRIGGERED if burn does not meet any ABA referral criteria

⸻

Not Evaluated When

• Superficial (first-degree) burns only
• Non-injury thermal exposure without tissue injury

⸻

Optional Missing-Data Hint

• Documented TBSA calculation
• Explicit burn depth description
• Clear identification of involved anatomic regions

⸻

Decision Flow (Authoritative Execution Logic)

START

Does the patient meet Applicability Gate?
• NO → STOP (Not Evaluated)
• YES → Continue

Is required trigger data present?
• NO → INDETERMINATE
• YES → Continue

Does patient meet trigger criteria?
• YES → TRIGGERED
• NO → NOT TRIGGERED

protocols.name: Management of Solid Organ Injuries

Protocol Class: •	Patient with blunt solid organ injury (liver, spleen, and/or kidney) identified on imaging
At least one of the following: •	Imaging-confirmed liver, spleen, or kidney injury (Grade I–V)
•	Hemoperitoneum associated with a solid organ injury
•	Hemodynamic instability temporally associated with a solid organ injury
•	Requirement for exploratory laparotomy for another acute injury in the presence of a solid organ injury
•	CT imaging confirming liver, spleen, and/or kidney injury
•	Presence or absence of contrast extravasation or pseudoaneurysm
•	Hemodynamic status after initial fluid resuscitation
•	Documentation regarding candidacy for angiography or embolization
•	Documentation of operative necessity for other acute injuries (if applicable)
•	CT-based injury identification during initial evaluation
•	Hemodynamic reassessment after initial fluid resuscitation
•	Early angiography consultation for high-grade injuries or vascular findings
•	Immediate operative intervention when instability persists or embolization is not appropriate
•	INDETERMINATE if injury grade cannot be determined
•	INDETERMINATE if post-resuscitation hemodynamic status is unclear
•	NOT TRIGGERED if no solid organ injury is identified
•	No solid organ injury is identified
•	Final CT report specifying injury grade and vascular findings
Does the patient meet Applicability Gate?

PROTOCOL: Management of Solid Organ Injuries

Protocol Class:
CLASS I — Triggerable Protocol

⸻

Applicability Gate
	•	Patient with blunt solid organ injury (liver, spleen, and/or kidney) identified on imaging

⸻

Trigger Criteria (Exact)

At least one of the following:
	•	Imaging-confirmed liver, spleen, or kidney injury (Grade I–V)
	•	Evidence of vascular injury, including:
	•	Contrast extravasation
	•	Pseudoaneurysm
	•	Hemoperitoneum associated with a solid organ injury
	•	Hemodynamic instability temporally associated with a solid organ injury
	•	Requirement for exploratory laparotomy for another acute injury in the presence of a solid organ injury

	•	Injury grade (I–V), when documented
	•	Presence or absence of contrast extravasation or pseudoaneurysm
	•	Estimated hemoperitoneum (none / moderate / large)
	•	Hemodynamic status after initial fluid resuscitation
	•	Documentation regarding candidacy for angiography or embolization
	•	Documentation of operative necessity for other acute injuries (if applicable)

	•	Early angiography consultation for high-grade injuries or vascular findings

	•	INDETERMINATE if injury grade cannot be determined
	•	INDETERMINATE if post-resuscitation hemodynamic status is unclear
	•	NOT TRIGGERED if no solid organ injury is identified

protocols.name: Management of Severe Musculoskeletal Injuries

Protocol Class: •	Trauma patient with suspected or confirmed severe musculoskeletal injury
At least one of the following orthopedic: •	Hemodynamically unstable pelvic fracture with pelvic ring instability, defined as two of the following three:
•	Systolic blood pressure < 90 mmHg on two documented readings
•	Fracture or dislocation with risk of avascular necrosis, including:
•	Femoral head dislocation prior to successful reduction
•	Talus fracture with subtalar dislocation prior to successful reduction
•	Documented vascular compromise associated with fracture or dislocation
•	Mechanism and anatomic location of musculoskeletal injury
•	Vital signs sufficient to assess hemodynamic status
•	Imaging confirming fracture or dislocation pattern
•	Documentation of reduction status, when applicable
•	Trauma Surgery or Orthopedic Surgery assessment note
•	Injury assessment during initial trauma evaluation
•	Timing of reduction relative to presentation
•	Timing of orthopedic consultation when emergency criteria are present
(Timing elements are evaluative only and do not create additional trigger logic.)
•	INDETERMINATE if hemodynamic status cannot be determined
•	INDETERMINATE if injury pattern or reduction status is unclear
•	NOT TRIGGERED if none of the orthopedic emergency criteria are documented
•	Minor musculoskeletal injuries without emergency features
•	Isolated injuries managed non-operatively without urgency
•	Clear documentation of vascular and neurologic examination
Does the patient meet Applicability Gate?

protocols.raw_block:
PROTOCOL: Management of Severe Musculoskeletal Injuries

Protocol Class:
CLASS I — Triggerable Protocol

⸻

Applicability Gate
	•	Trauma patient with suspected or confirmed severe musculoskeletal injury

⸻

Trigger Criteria (Exact)

At least one of the following orthopedic emergency conditions:

Pelvic Injury
	•	Hemodynamically unstable pelvic fracture with pelvic ring instability, defined as two of the following three:
	•	Systolic blood pressure < 90 mmHg on two documented readings
	•	Heart rate > 100 beats per minute
	•	Respiratory rate > 30 breaths per minute
	•	Excludes isolated pubic rami fractures

Extremity Emergencies
	•	Suspected extremity compartment syndrome
	•	Fracture or dislocation with risk of avascular necrosis, including:
	•	Femoral head dislocation prior to successful reduction
	•	Talus fracture with subtalar dislocation prior to successful reduction
	•	Documented vascular compromise associated with fracture or dislocation

⸻

Required Data Elements
	•	Mechanism and anatomic location of musculoskeletal injury
	•	Vital signs sufficient to assess hemodynamic status
	•	Imaging confirming fracture or dislocation pattern
	•	Physical examination documenting:
	•	Compartment status and/or
	•	Vascular compromise
	•	Documentation of reduction status, when applicable
	•	Trauma Surgery or Orthopedic Surgery assessment note

⸻

Authoritative Sources
	•	Trauma H&P
	•	Physician notes
	•	Nursing documentation
	•	Imaging reports
	•	Operative notes
	•	Orthopedic Surgery documentation

⸻

Timing-Critical Elements
	•	Injury assessment during initial trauma evaluation
	•	Timing of reduction relative to presentation
	•	Timing of orthopedic consultation when emergency criteria are present

(Timing elements are evaluative only and do not create additional trigger logic.)

⸻

Failure Behavior
	•	INDETERMINATE if hemodynamic status cannot be determined
	•	INDETERMINATE if injury pattern or reduction status is unclear
	•	NOT TRIGGERED if none of the orthopedic emergency criteria are documented

⸻

Not Evaluated When
	•	Minor musculoskeletal injuries without emergency features
	•	Isolated injuries managed non-operatively without urgency

⸻

Optional Missing-Data Hint
	•	Complete vital sign documentation
	•	Definitive imaging reports
	•	Clear documentation of vascular and neurologic examination

⸻

START

Does the patient meet Applicability Gate?
	•	NO → STOP (Not Evaluated)
	•	YES → Continue

Is required trigger data present?
	•	NO → INDETERMINATE
	•	YES → Continue

Does patient meet trigger criteria?
	•	YES → TRIGGERED
	•	NO → NOT TRIGGERED

protocols.name: Management of Neurosurgical Emergencies

Protocol Class: •	Trauma patient with suspected or confirmed traumatic brain injury (TBI) or
•	Trauma patient with suspected spinal cord injury
At least one of the following objectivel: •	Head CT evidence of intracranial traumatic pathology
•	Head CT evidence of a potential intracranial mass lesion (e.g., subdural hematoma, epidural hematoma, intraparenchymal hemorrhage, contusion with mass effect)
•	Documented neurologic deficit attributable to suspected spinal cord injury
•	Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score with timing
•	Spinal imaging and/or examination findings when spinal cord injury is suspected
•	Imaging reports (CT head, CT spine, MRI spine when obtained)
•	Timing of neurosurgical consultation request relative to identification of emergency criteria
•	Documentation of neurosurgical evaluation or communication when consultation occurs
(Timing elements are evaluative only and do not create additional trigger logic.)
•	INDETERMINATE if GCS is not documented
•	INDETERMINATE if head CT results are unavailable or unclear
•	INDETERMINATE if a neurologic deficit is suspected but not documented
•	NOT TRIGGERED if none of the neurosurgical emergency criteria are documented
•	No evidence or suspicion of traumatic brain injury
•	No evidence or suspicion of spinal cord injury
•	Neurologically intact patients without qualifying imaging findings
•	Detailed neurologic examination documenting presence or absence of deficit
Does the patient meet Applicability Gate?

protocols.raw_block:
PROTOCOL: Management of Neurosurgical Emergencies

Protocol Class:
CLASS I — Triggerable Protocol

⸻

Applicability Gate
	•	Trauma patient with suspected or confirmed traumatic brain injury (TBI) or
	•	Trauma patient with suspected spinal cord injury

⸻

Trigger Criteria (Exact)

At least one of the following objectively defined neurosurgical emergency conditions:

Traumatic Brain Injury
	•	Severe TBI, defined as:
	•	Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) < 9, and
	•	Head CT evidence of intracranial traumatic pathology
	•	Moderate TBI, defined as:
	•	GCS 9–12, and
	•	Head CT evidence of a potential intracranial mass lesion (e.g., subdural hematoma, epidural hematoma, intraparenchymal hemorrhage, contusion with mass effect)

Spinal Cord Injury
	•	Documented neurologic deficit attributable to suspected spinal cord injury

⸻

Required Data Elements
	•	Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score with timing
	•	Head CT imaging results
	•	Neurologic examination documenting focal deficits
	•	Spinal imaging and/or examination findings when spinal cord injury is suspected

⸻

Authoritative Sources
	•	Trauma H&P
	•	Physician notes
	•	Nursing documentation
	•	Imaging reports (CT head, CT spine, MRI spine when obtained)

⸻

Timing-Critical Elements
	•	Timing of neurosurgical consultation request relative to identification of emergency criteria
	•	Documentation of neurosurgical evaluation or communication when consultation occurs

(Timing elements are evaluative only and do not create additional trigger logic.)

⸻

Failure Behavior
	•	INDETERMINATE if GCS is not documented
	•	INDETERMINATE if head CT results are unavailable or unclear
	•	INDETERMINATE if a neurologic deficit is suspected but not documented
	•	NOT TRIGGERED if none of the neurosurgical emergency criteria are documented

⸻

Not Evaluated When
	•	No evidence or suspicion of traumatic brain injury
	•	No evidence or suspicion of spinal cord injury
	•	Neurologically intact patients without qualifying imaging findings

Optional Missing-Data Hint

	•	Final head CT report
	•	Detailed neurologic examination documenting presence or absence of deficit

	•	YES → Continue

Is required trigger data present?
	•	NO → INDETERMINATE
	•	YES → Continue

Does patient meet trigger criteria?
	•	YES → TRIGGERED
	•	NO → NOT TRIGGERED

protocols.name: Spinal Clearance and Spinal Injury Management

Protocol Class: •	Trauma patient with blunt force trauma and clinical concern for spinal injury
(Concern may arise from mechanism, symptoms, or examination findings; concern alone does not trigger.)
At least one of the following objective: •	Neurologic deficit involving torso, arms, or legs not explained by peripheral nerve injury, including:
•	Midline spinal pain or tenderness to palpation
•	Radiographic abnormality of the cervical, thoracic, or lumbar spine identified on CT imaging
•	Documentation of spinal tenderness or pain
•	CT imaging of cervical, thoracic, and/or lumbar spine when criteria are met
•	Rectal tone documentation when clinically indicated
•	NEXUS criteria assessment only if applied (not required)
•	Spinal motion restriction initiated upon clinical concern for injury
•	CT imaging obtained promptly when trigger criteria are present
•	Cervical collar removal only by physician order after clearance
•	Long spine board removal as soon as feasible per physician order
•	Neurologic deficits attributable to spinal cord injury
(Timing elements inform evaluation but do not independently trigger.)
•	INDETERMINATE if neurologic examination is incomplete or not documented
•	INDETERMINATE if spinal tenderness assessment is not documented
•	INDETERMINATE if imaging is indicated but results are unavailable or unclear
•	NOT TRIGGERED if no spinal symptoms, neurologic findings, or radiographic abnormalities are documented
•	Isolated peripheral nerve injury without spinal involvement
•	Explicit documentation of spinal tenderness or absence thereof
Does the patient meet Applicability Gate?

protocols.raw_block:
PROTOCOL: Spinal Clearance and Spinal Injury Management

Protocol Class:
CLASS I — Triggerable Protocol

⸻

Applicability Gate
	•	Trauma patient with blunt force trauma and clinical concern for spinal injury

(Concern may arise from mechanism, symptoms, or examination findings; concern alone does not trigger.)

⸻

Trigger Criteria (Exact)

At least one of the following objective spinal injury indicators:

Neurologic Indicators
	•	Neurologic deficit involving torso, arms, or legs not explained by peripheral nerve injury, including:
	•	Weakness
	•	Paresthesia
	•	Sensory loss

Pain / Examination Findings
	•	Midline spinal pain or tenderness to palpation
	•	Abnormal spinal examination, including:
	•	Spinous process step-off
	•	Abnormal kyphosis

Imaging-Based Indicators
	•	Radiographic abnormality of the cervical, thoracic, or lumbar spine identified on CT imaging

⸻

Required Data Elements
	•	Mechanism confirming blunt trauma
	•	Spine physical examination findings
	•	Complete neurologic examination (motor and sensory)
	•	Documentation of spinal tenderness or pain
	•	CT imaging of cervical, thoracic, and/or lumbar spine when criteria are met
	•	Rectal tone documentation when clinically indicated
	•	NEXUS criteria assessment only if applied (not required)

⸻

Authoritative Sources
	•	Trauma H&P
	•	Physician notes
	•	Nursing documentation
	•	Imaging reports (CT cervical/thoracic/lumbar spine)
	•	Neurosurgery consultation documentation (if obtained)

⸻

Timing-Critical Elements
	•	Spinal motion restriction initiated upon clinical concern for injury
	•	CT imaging obtained promptly when trigger criteria are present
	•	Cervical collar removal only by physician order after clearance
	•	Long spine board removal as soon as feasible per physician order
	•	Neurosurgery consultation required for:
	•	Radiographic spinal abnormalities
	•	Neurologic deficits attributable to spinal cord injury

(Timing elements inform evaluation but do not independently trigger.)

⸻

Failure Behavior
	•	INDETERMINATE if neurologic examination is incomplete or not documented
	•	INDETERMINATE if spinal tenderness assessment is not documented
	•	INDETERMINATE if imaging is indicated but results are unavailable or unclear
	•	NOT TRIGGERED if no spinal symptoms, neurologic findings, or radiographic abnormalities are documented

⸻

Not Evaluated When
	•	No blunt trauma
	•	Isolated peripheral nerve injury without spinal involvement
	•	Non-trauma admissions

⸻

Optional Missing-Data Hint
	•	Complete neurologic examination documentation
	•	Explicit documentation of spinal tenderness or absence thereof
	•	Final CT spine reports
	•	Physician order addressing spinal clearance

⸻

Decision Flow (Authoritative Execution Logic)

START

Does the patient meet Applicability Gate?
	•	NO → STOP (Not Evaluated)
	•	YES → Continue

Is required trigger data present?
	•	NO → INDETERMINATE
	•	YES → Continue

Does patient meet trigger criteria?
	•	YES → TRIGGERED
	•	NO → NOT TRIGGERED

protocols.name: Management and Stabilization of Pelvic Fractures

Protocol Class: •	Trauma patient with suspected or confirmed pelvic ring injury
(Suspicion alone does not trigger; criteria below determine execution.)
At least one of the following pelvic ins: •	Hemodynamic instability where pelvic fracture is a suspected source of hemorrhage
•	Open pelvic fracture or pelvic fracture communicating with:
•	Displaced pubic rami fracture(s) associated with pelvic ring instability
•	Pelvic fracture with evidence of associated urologic injury (e.g., gross hematuria)
•	Pelvic imaging (pelvic x-ray and/or CT pelvis when stable)
•	Pelvic fracture pattern characterization (stable vs unstable)
•	Documentation of pelvic binder placement and timing (if applied)
•	Pelvic x-ray and FAST performed during initial trauma bay evaluation
•	Pelvic binder applied immediately for suspected unstable pelvic fracture or pelvic-related hemorrhage
•	Pelvic binder is temporary and must be removed within 24 hours by physician order
•	Portable pelvic x-ray obtained after binder placement
•	External fixation prioritized before laparotomy in most cases
•	Retrograde urethrogram considered when gross hematuria or urethral injury is suspected
(Timing elements inform care; they do not independently trigger.)
•	INDETERMINATE if pelvic fracture pattern cannot be determined
•	INDETERMINATE if hemodynamic status is unclear
•	NOT TRIGGERED if pelvic imaging confirms a stable pelvic ring injury without hemorrhage or instability
•	Isolated hip fracture without pelvic ring involvement
•	Clear documentation of binder placement time and indication
Does the patient meet Applicability Gate?

protocols.raw_block:
PROTOCOL: Management and Stabilization of Pelvic Fractures

Protocol Class:
CLASS I — Triggerable Protocol

⸻

Applicability Gate
	•	Trauma patient with suspected or confirmed pelvic ring injury

(Suspicion alone does not trigger; criteria below determine execution.)

⸻

Trigger Criteria (Exact)

At least one of the following pelvic instability or hemorrhage indicators:

Hemodynamic / Hemorrhage Indicators
	•	Hemodynamic instability where pelvic fracture is a suspected source of hemorrhage
	•	Open pelvic fracture or pelvic fracture communicating with:
	•	Perineum
	•	Rectum
	•	Vagina
	•	Buttocks

Imaging-Confirmed Unstable Pelvic Ring Patterns
	•	2.5 cm pubic symphysis diastasis
	•	Displaced pubic rami fracture(s) associated with pelvic ring instability
	•	1 cm sacroiliac joint widening
	•	1 cm displaced sacral fracture(s)
	•	Sacroiliac joint fracture-dislocation
	•	Hemipelvis vertical or rotational migration

Associated High-Risk Findings
	•	Pelvic fracture with evidence of associated urologic injury (e.g., gross hematuria)

⸻

Required Data Elements
	•	Mechanism of injury
	•	Hemodynamic status and vital signs
	•	Pelvic imaging (pelvic x-ray and/or CT pelvis when stable)
	•	FAST examination results
	•	Pelvic fracture pattern characterization (stable vs unstable)
	•	Documentation of pelvic binder placement and timing (if applied)
	•	Evidence of associated urologic injury

⸻

Authoritative Sources
	•	Trauma H&P
	•	Physician notes
	•	Nursing documentation
	•	Imaging reports (pelvic x-ray, CT pelvis)
	•	Operative notes
	•	Orthopedic Surgery documentation

⸻

Timing-Critical Elements
	•	Pelvic x-ray and FAST performed during initial trauma bay evaluation
	•	Pelvic binder applied immediately for suspected unstable pelvic fracture or pelvic-related hemorrhage
	•	Pelvic binder is temporary and must be removed within 24 hours by physician order
	•	Portable pelvic x-ray obtained after binder placement
	•	External fixation prioritized before laparotomy in most cases
	•	Retrograde urethrogram considered when gross hematuria or urethral injury is suspected

(Timing elements inform care; they do not independently trigger.)

⸻

Failure Behavior
	•	INDETERMINATE if pelvic fracture pattern cannot be determined
	•	INDETERMINATE if hemodynamic status is unclear
	•	NOT TRIGGERED if pelvic imaging confirms a stable pelvic ring injury without hemorrhage or instability

⸻

Not Evaluated When
	•	No pelvic injury identified
	•	Isolated hip fracture without pelvic ring involvement

⸻

Optional Missing-Data Hint
	•	Definitive pelvic imaging report
	•	Clear documentation of binder placement time and indication
	•	Orthopedic assessment describing pelvic stability

⸻

Decision Flow (Authoritative Execution Logic)

START

Does the patient meet Applicability Gate?
	•	NO → STOP (Not Evaluated)
	•	YES → Continue

Is required trigger data present?
	•	NO → INDETERMINATE
	•	YES → Continue

Does patient meet trigger criteria?
	•	YES → TRIGGERED
	•	NO → NOT TRIGGERED

protocols.name: Management of the Orthopedic/Neurologic Splint and/or Brace

Protocol Class: This protocol applies only when a trauma patient has an orthopedic and/or neurologic splint, cast, brace, or immobilization device in place.
Includes: •	Devices applied at an outside facility prior to transfer
This protocol becomes applicable when an: •	Presence of an orthopedic or neurologic device (e.g., cast, splint, knee immobilizer, cervical collar, back brace, Bucks traction boots)
•	Transfer from an outside facility with a cast or splint in place
•	Requirement for skin assessment related to an orthopedic/neurologic device
•	Identification of skin integrity concerns beneath a device
Execution Rules
•	This protocol must NOT be evaluated as Triggered / Not Triggered / Indeterminate
•	When applicable, it must render as:
“Applicable — contextual protocol”
•	If no qualifying context is documented, the protocol is silently omitted
•	Missing context is not logged as a failure
Required Data Elements (When Applicable)
•	Presence and type of orthopedic/neurologic device
•	Surgical plan and timing (within 24 hours vs not)
•	Physician order authorizing device removal for skin assessment
•	Documentation of skin assessment findings
•	Ortho/Uro Specialist (OUS) consult placement and response
•	Documentation of circulation, motor function, and sensation
Authoritative Sources
•	Trauma H&P
•	Physician notes
•	Nursing documentation
•	Orthopedic and/or Neurosurgery documentation
•	Ortho/Uro Specialist consult documentation
•	Wound Ostomy Continence Nurse (WOCN) documentation (if applicable)
Timing & Process Expectations (Non-Triggering)
•	OUS consult placed by admitting RN for all patients with orthopedic/neurologic devices
•	OUS bedside consult within 24 hours of placement
•	RN skin assessment every shift
•	Device removal only after physician order
•	Collaboration between RN and OUS during overnight hours (1900–0700)
•	Immediate WOCN consult when skin integrity concerns are identified
(These elements guide care but do not create trigger logic.)
Failure Semantics
•	Missing documentation does not convert this protocol into Triggered / Not Triggered
•	Documentation gaps may be surfaced via:
•	run debug — protocols
•	Governance checklist failure
•	No patient-facing failure state is generated
Not Applicable When
•	No orthopedic or neurologic splint, brace, cast, or immobilization device is present
•	Non-trauma admissions without device management requirements

protocols.name: Rib Fracture Management

Protocol Class: •	Trauma patient with imaging-confirmed rib fracture(s)
At least one of the following: •	Fractures of ribs 3 through 10 and three or more ribs with at least two of the following:
•	Poor cough or poor secretion clearance
(Failure to meet ORIF criteria does not negate protocol triggering.)
•	Imaging confirming rib fractures and rib numbering
•	Nursing or respiratory therapy documentation of cough and secretion clearance
•	Incentive spirometry and secretion clearance measures initiated on admission
•	Early mobility initiated as clinically appropriate
•	If ORIF-eligible, surgical fixation should occur within 72 hours of admission
•	INDETERMINATE if rib numbering is unclear
•	INDETERMINATE if required respiratory or pain data are missing
•	NOT TRIGGERED if no qualifying rib fractures are identified
(Clinical exclusions such as shock, sepsis, or severe TBI affect ORIF candidacy but do not negate protocol triggering and must be documented explicitly.)
•	Detailed imaging report specifying rib numbers
•	Trauma Surgeon documentation addressing ORIF candidacy
Does the patient meet Applicability Gate?
If TRIGGERED → evaluate ORIF eligibility criteria
•	Does not meet ORIF criteria → Non-operative rib fracture management

protocols.raw_block:
PROTOCOL: Rib Fracture Management

Protocol Class:
CLASS I — Triggerable Protocol

⸻

Applicability Gate
	•	Trauma patient with imaging-confirmed rib fracture(s)
	•	Patient ≥ 18 years of age

⸻

Trigger Criteria (Exact)

At least one of the following:
	•	One or more imaging-confirmed rib fractures involving ribs 3 through 10
	•	Flail chest involving any rib segment

⸻

ORIF Eligibility Criteria (Evaluated After Trigger)

Evaluated only if protocol is triggered.

At least one of the following:
	•	Flail chest involving ribs 3 through 10
	•	Fractures of ribs 3 through 10 and three or more ribs with at least two of the following:
	•	Respiratory rate > 20 breaths per minute
	•	Incentive spirometry < 50% predicted
	•	Uncontrolled pain despite multimodal therapy
	•	Poor cough or poor secretion clearance

(Failure to meet ORIF criteria does not negate protocol triggering.)

⸻

Required Data Elements
	•	Imaging confirming rib fractures and rib numbering
	•	Patient age
	•	Respiratory rate
	•	Incentive spirometry values (percent predicted)
	•	Pain assessment documentation
	•	Nursing or respiratory therapy documentation of cough and secretion clearance

⸻

Authoritative Sources
	•	Trauma H&P
	•	Physician notes
	•	Nursing documentation
	•	Imaging reports
	•	Respiratory therapy documentation

⸻

Timing-Critical Elements
	•	Incentive spirometry and secretion clearance measures initiated on admission
	•	Early multimodal pain control
	•	Head of bed maintained > 30°
	•	Early mobility initiated as clinically appropriate
	•	If ORIF-eligible, surgical fixation should occur within 72 hours of admission

⸻

Failure Behavior
	•	INDETERMINATE if rib numbering is unclear
	•	INDETERMINATE if required respiratory or pain data are missing
	•	NOT TRIGGERED if no qualifying rib fractures are identified

⸻

Not Evaluated When
	•	No rib fractures are identified
	•	Non-trauma admissions

(Clinical exclusions such as shock, sepsis, or severe TBI affect ORIF candidacy but do not negate protocol triggering and must be documented explicitly.)

⸻

Optional Missing-Data Hint
	•	Detailed imaging report specifying rib numbers
	•	Documented incentive spirometry percent predicted
	•	Trauma Surgeon documentation addressing ORIF candidacy

⸻

Decision Flow (Authoritative Execution Logic)

START

Does the patient meet Applicability Gate?
	•	NO → STOP (Not Evaluated)
	•	YES → Continue

Are qualifying rib fractures present?
	•	NO → NOT TRIGGERED
	•	YES → TRIGGERED

If TRIGGERED → evaluate ORIF eligibility criteria
	•	Meets ORIF criteria → ORIF-eligible
	•	Does not meet ORIF criteria → Non-operative rib fracture management

protocols.name: Monitoring Base Deficit

Applicability Gate: • Category I trauma patient
• OR trauma patient explicitly designated by Trauma Surgeon for shock/resuscitation assessment
At least one of the following: • Explicit Trauma Surgeon designation for base deficit monitoring
Required Data Elements: • Arterial or venous blood gas with base deficit value
• Timing of blood gas draw relative to arrival
• Documentation of Trauma Surgeon cancellation, if applicable
Authoritative Sources: • Laboratory data (arterial or venous blood gas)
Execution Rules (Authoritative): • All Category I trauma patients MUST have a blood gas obtained with base deficit.
• This requirement applies regardless of the numeric base deficit value.
• Numeric base deficit values modify monitoring behavior only and do not affect triggering.
Monitoring Logic: • Initial base deficit obtained on admission.
– Monitor every 2 hours until base deficit is improving.
– Once improving, monitor every 4 hours until Base Deficit < 4
OR until patient is otherwise clinically resuscitated.
– Further monitoring at Trauma Surgeon discretion.
• Trauma Surgeon may explicitly cancel further base deficit monitoring at any time.
Failure Behavior: • INDETERMINATE if Category I status is present and no base deficit is obtained
AND no explicit Trauma Surgeon cancellation is documented.
• NOT TRIGGERED if patient is not Category I
AND no Trauma Surgeon designation exists.
Not Evaluated When: • Non-trauma admissions
• Trauma patients who are not Category I and not designated by Trauma Surgeon
Optional Missing-Data Hint: • Initial blood gas result with base deficit value
• Documentation of Trauma Surgeon cancellation or continuation decision
Decision Flow (Authoritative Execution L: Is the patient Category I OR explicitly designated by Trauma Surgeon?
Is base deficit obtained or explicitly cancelled?

protocols.raw_block:
PROTOCOL: Monitoring Base Deficit

Protocol Class:
CLASS I — Triggerable Protocol

Applicability Gate:
• Category I trauma patient
• OR trauma patient explicitly designated by Trauma Surgeon for shock/resuscitation assessment

Trigger Criteria (Exact):
At least one of the following:
• Category I trauma activation
• Explicit Trauma Surgeon designation for base deficit monitoring

Required Data Elements:
• Arterial or venous blood gas with base deficit value
• Timing of blood gas draw relative to arrival
• Documentation of Trauma Surgeon cancellation, if applicable

Authoritative Sources:
• Trauma H&P
• Physician notes
• Nursing documentation
• Laboratory data (arterial or venous blood gas)

Execution Rules (Authoritative):
• All Category I trauma patients MUST have a blood gas obtained with base deficit.
• This requirement applies regardless of the numeric base deficit value.
• Numeric base deficit values modify monitoring behavior only and do not affect triggering.

Monitoring Logic:
• Initial base deficit obtained on admission.
• If Base Deficit > 4:
  – Monitor every 2 hours until base deficit is improving.
  – Once improving, monitor every 4 hours until Base Deficit < 4
    OR until patient is otherwise clinically resuscitated.
• If Base Deficit ≤ 4:
  – Further monitoring at Trauma Surgeon discretion.
• Trauma Surgeon may explicitly cancel further base deficit monitoring at any time.

Failure Behavior:
• INDETERMINATE if Category I status is present and no base deficit is obtained
  AND no explicit Trauma Surgeon cancellation is documented.
• NOT TRIGGERED if patient is not Category I
  AND no Trauma Surgeon designation exists.

Not Evaluated When:
• Non-trauma admissions
• Trauma patients who are not Category I and not designated by Trauma Surgeon

Optional Missing-Data Hint:
• Initial blood gas result with base deficit value
• Documentation of Trauma Surgeon cancellation or continuation decision

⸻

Decision Flow (Authoritative Execution Logic):

START

Is the patient Category I OR explicitly designated by Trauma Surgeon?
• NO → STOP (Not Triggered)
• YES → Continue

Is base deficit obtained or explicitly cancelled?
• NO → INDETERMINATE
• YES → Continue

Protocol = TRIGGERED

protocols.name: Penetrating Chest Injury

Applicability Gate: • Patient with penetrating injury to the thorax,
defined as the region bounded by the clavicles superiorly
and the costal margins inferiorly
Arrest Recognition Criteria (Triggers Em: • Patient presents pulseless with signs of life after penetrating thoracic injury
• Patient suffers cardiac arrest after arrival to the trauma bay following penetrating chest injury
• Hemodynamic instability after penetrating chest injury
• Respiratory distress after penetrating chest injury with concern for:
Massive Hemothorax Criteria: • Initial chest tube output > 1500 mL, OR
• Ongoing chest tube drainage > 200 mL/hour for 2–3 hours
Tamponade Criteria: • FAST exam positive for pericardial fluid in a penetrating chest injury
Required Data Elements: • Mechanism confirming penetrating thoracic injury
• Presence or absence of cardiac arrest
• Presence or absence of signs of life (blood pressure, cardiac electrical activity, respiratory effort)
• Vital signs documenting hemodynamic status
• Respiratory status documentation
• FAST examination result (if performed)
• Chest tube output volumes with timing (if placed)
• Chest imaging results (portable AP chest x-ray and/or CT chest)
Timing-Critical Elements: • Determination of arrest and signs of life at presentation or during resuscitation
• Immediate progression to left anterior thoracotomy in qualifying arrest scenarios
• FAST exam performed contemporaneously when tamponade is suspected
• Chest tube output thresholds assessed in real time
Failure Behavior: • INDETERMINATE if signs of life status is not documented
• INDETERMINATE if chest tube output volumes or timing are unclear
• INDETERMINATE if FAST result is not documented when indicated
• NOT TRIGGERED if penetrating injury does not involve the thorax
• NOT TRIGGERED if penetrating thoracic injury is documented without
hemodynamic instability, respiratory distress, tamponade,
massive hemothorax, or arrest criteria
Not Evaluated When: • Blunt chest trauma
• Penetrating injuries isolated to the abdomen or neck without thoracic involvement
Optional Missing-Data Hint: • Explicit documentation of signs of life
• Chest tube output totals with timestamps
Decision Flow (Authoritative Execution L: Does the patient meet Applicability Gate?

PROTOCOL: Penetrating Chest Injury

Protocol Class:
CLASS I — Triggerable Protocol

Applicability Gate:
• Patient with penetrating injury to the thorax,

Trigger Criteria (Exact):

Arrest Recognition Criteria (Triggers Emergent Resuscitative Thoracotomy / Traumatic Arrest Protocols):

Non-Arrest, Unstable / Distress Criteria:

Massive Hemothorax Criteria:
• Initial chest tube output > 1500 mL, OR
• Ongoing chest tube drainage > 200 mL/hour for 2–3 hours

Tamponade Criteria:
• FAST exam positive for pericardial fluid in a penetrating chest injury

Required Data Elements:
• Mechanism confirming penetrating thoracic injury
• Presence or absence of cardiac arrest
• Presence or absence of signs of life (blood pressure, cardiac electrical activity, respiratory effort)
• Vital signs documenting hemodynamic status
• Respiratory status documentation

Timing-Critical Elements:
• Determination of arrest and signs of life at presentation or during resuscitation

• FAST exam performed contemporaneously when tamponade is suspected
• Chest tube output thresholds assessed in real time

Failure Behavior:
• INDETERMINATE if signs of life status is not documented
• INDETERMINATE if chest tube output volumes or timing are unclear
• INDETERMINATE if FAST result is not documented when indicated
• NOT TRIGGERED if penetrating injury does not involve the thorax

  hemodynamic instability, respiratory distress, tamponade,

Not Evaluated When:
• Blunt chest trauma

Optional Missing-Data Hint:

• Chest tube output totals with timestamps

⸻

Decision Flow (Authoritative Execution Logic):

START

Does the patient meet Applicability Gate?
• NO → STOP (Not Evaluated)
• YES → Continue

Is required trigger data present?
• NO → INDETERMINATE
• YES → Continue

Does patient meet trigger criteria?
• YES → TRIGGERED
• NO → NOT TRIGGERED

protocols.name: ROTEM Guideline

Applicability Gate: • Trauma patient with Massive Transfusion Protocol (MTP) activation, OR
• Trauma patient receiving ED Blood Box or balanced blood resuscitation for ongoing hemorrhage
Required Data Elements: • Documentation of MTP activation or ED Blood Box use
• ROTEM trauma panel ordered (EXTEM and FIBTEM)
• ROTEM parameters with values and timing:
– EXTEM CT (coagulation time)
– EXTEM A10
– FIBTEM A10
– EXTEM ML (maximum lysis)
• Specimen collection documentation (blue top tube, hand-delivered to lab)
Timing-Critical Elements: • ROTEM ordered during active hemorrhagic resuscitation
• ROTEM may be ordered at any point during MTP
• Results viewable in real time for up to 60 minutes on Epic Dashboard
• Treatment decisions guided by ROTEM values:
– EXTEM CT > 80 sec → FFP
– EXTEM A10 < 40 mm → evaluate FIBTEM A10
– FIBTEM A10 < 10 mm → Cryoprecipitate
– FIBTEM A10 ≥ 10 mm → Platelets
– EXTEM ML ≥ 15% with “fish shape” in EXTEM/FIBTEM → TXA
• Repeat ROTEM if bleeding persists after targeted intervention
Failure Behavior: • INDETERMINATE if Applicability Gate is met but ROTEM is not ordered
• INDETERMINATE if specimen handling requirements are not met
• INDETERMINATE if ROTEM parameters or timing are not documented
• NOT TRIGGERED only when Applicability Gate is not met
Not Evaluated When: • No hemorrhagic resuscitation
• No MTP activation and no ED Blood Box or balanced blood resuscitation
Optional Missing-Data Hint: • Completed ROTEM trauma panel with timestamps
• Documentation confirming proper specimen collection and hand delivery
• Repeat ROTEM results during ongoing hemorrhage
Decision Flow (Authoritative Execution L: Does the patient meet Applicability Gate?

protocols.name: Vascular Intervention Guideline

Applicability Gate: • Trauma patient with suspected or confirmed hemorrhage where vascular intervention for hemorrhage control is being considered
At least one of the following vascular c: Category A — VASCULAR EMERGENCY (Rapid Response Required)
All of the following are required: • Confirmed hypotension, defined as more than one blood pressure reading < 90 mmHg in adults, or age-specific hypotension in pediatric patients
• Active arterial extravasation on CT imaging, or
• Pseudoaneurysm (e.g., liver, spleen, or other organ)
• Does not meet Category A criteria
Required Data Elements: • Blood pressure measurements (with confirmation of more than one reading)
• Documentation of blood transfusion initiation
• CT imaging demonstrating arterial extravasation or pseudoaneurysm
• Determination of angioembolizable lesion
• Trauma Surgeon or treating physician determination regarding need for intervention
Authoritative Sources: • Imaging reports (CT angiography or contrast CT)
Timing-Critical Elements: • Category A — Vascular Emergency:
• Angioembolization procedure must begin within 60 minutes of Trauma Vascular Emergency activation
• Response time is tracked from request to arterial puncture
• Category B — Vascular Intervention Consideration:
• Timing of angioembolization is at the discretion of the surgeon if intervention is deemed necessary
• Solid organ injuries should be evaluated in conjunction with the Management of Solid Organ Injuries guideline
Failure Behavior: • INDETERMINATE if blood pressure readings are incomplete or not confirmed
• INDETERMINATE if transfusion status is unclear
• INDETERMINATE if imaging does not clearly demonstrate an angioembolizable lesion
• NOT TRIGGERED if criteria for neither Category A nor Category B are met
Not Evaluated When: • No evidence of hemorrhage requiring vascular control
• No angioembolizable lesion identified
Optional Missing-Data Hint: • Clear CT imaging report specifying arterial extravasation or pseudoaneurysm
Decision Flow (Authoritative Execution L: Does the patient meet Applicability Gate?

PROTOCOL: Vascular Intervention Guideline

Protocol Class:
CLASS I — Triggerable Protocol

Applicability Gate:

Trigger Criteria (Exact):
At least one of the following vascular categories:

Category A — VASCULAR EMERGENCY (Rapid Response Required)

All of the following are required:
• Blood transfusion initiated
• Confirmed hypotension, defined as more than one blood pressure reading < 90 mmHg in adults, or age-specific hypotension in pediatric patients
• Presence of an angioembolizable lesion

Category B — Vascular Intervention Consideration (Non-Emergency)

• Active arterial extravasation on CT imaging, or
• Pseudoaneurysm (e.g., liver, spleen, or other organ)
• Does not meet Category A criteria

Required Data Elements:
• Blood pressure measurements (with confirmation of more than one reading)
• Documentation of blood transfusion initiation
• CT imaging demonstrating arterial extravasation or pseudoaneurysm
• Determination of angioembolizable lesion
• Trauma Surgeon or treating physician determination regarding need for intervention

Authoritative Sources:

• Physician notes
• Nursing documentation
• Imaging reports (CT angiography or contrast CT)
• Interventional Radiology documentation

Timing-Critical Elements:
• Category A — Vascular Emergency:
• Angioembolization procedure must begin within 60 minutes of Trauma Vascular Emergency activation
• Response time is tracked from request to arterial puncture
• Category B — Vascular Intervention Consideration:
• Timing of angioembolization is at the discretion of the surgeon if intervention is deemed necessary
• Solid organ injuries should be evaluated in conjunction with the Management of Solid Organ Injuries guideline

Failure Behavior:
• INDETERMINATE if blood pressure readings are incomplete or not confirmed
• INDETERMINATE if transfusion status is unclear
• INDETERMINATE if imaging does not clearly demonstrate an angioembolizable lesion

Not Evaluated When:

Optional Missing-Data Hint:

⸻

START

Does the patient meet Applicability Gate?

• YES → Continue

Is required trigger data present?
• NO → INDETERMINATE
• YES → Continue

Does patient meet trigger criteria?
• YES → TRIGGERED

protocols.name: Suspected Hanging Guideline

Applicability Gate: • Patient presenting with suspected hanging, defined as intentional or unintentional asphyxiation by ligature or other constricting mechanism around the neck
Required Data Elements: • History consistent with hanging mechanism
• Physical examination findings of neck, airway, and neurologic status
• Vital signs and oxygenation status
• Imaging results obtained based on examination and history
• Documentation identifying presence or absence of traumatic injury
• Documentation identifying presence or absence of anoxic brain injury
Timing-Critical Elements: • Immediate airway and cervical spine assessment
• Early neurologic evaluation for hypoxic or anoxic injury
• Trauma activation initiated upon identification of hanging mechanism per activation criteria
• Imaging obtained based on clinical findings (CT head, CT cervical spine, CTA neck as indicated)
Failure Behavior: • INDETERMINATE if hanging mechanism cannot be confirmed or excluded based on available documentation
• NOT TRIGGERED only if Applicability Gate is not met
Not Evaluated When: • No history or concern for hanging mechanism
• Non-asphyxiation neck injuries without ligature or constricting mechanism
Optional Missing-Data Hint: • EMS or witness documentation clarifying mechanism
• Explicit physician documentation addressing presence or absence of hanging
• Imaging reports clarifying traumatic vs anoxic injury
Decision Flow (Authoritative Execution L: Does the patient meet Applicability Gate?
