• INDETERMINATE if hanging mechanism cannot be confirmed or excluded based on available documentation
• NOT TRIGGERED only if Applicability Gate is not met

Not Evaluated When:
• No history or concern for hanging mechanism
• Non-asphyxiation neck injuries without ligature or constricting mechanism

Optional Missing-Data Hint:
• EMS or witness documentation clarifying mechanism
• Explicit physician documentation addressing presence or absence of hanging
• Imaging reports clarifying traumatic vs anoxic injury

START

Does the patient meet Applicability Gate?
• NO → STOP (Not Evaluated)
• YES → TRIGGERED

protocols.name: Blood and Blood Product Transfusion

Applicability Gate: • Trauma patient undergoing active resuscitation for hemorrhage or suspected hemorrhagic shock
• Includes all Category I trauma activations
• Includes any trauma patient in whom blood product transfusion is initiated or anticipated
Required Data Elements: • Documentation of blood product administration (PRBCs, plasma, platelets, cryoprecipitate)
• Vital signs supporting hemorrhage or suspected hemorrhagic shock
• Documentation of anticipated transfusion need (if blood not yet administered)
• Documentation of MTP activation and Blood Bank notification (if applicable)
• Timing of transfusion initiation relative to arrival
• Laboratory data when obtained (type and cross, fibrinogen, ionized calcium, ROTEM if ordered)
Timing-Critical Elements: • Type and cross sent promptly when transfusion is anticipated
• Emergency-release PRBCs available immediately for Category I activations
• MTP initiated when massive transfusion is anticipated
• Blood product availability benchmarks after Blood Bank receives sample:
– PRBCs (type and cross): ~45 minutes
– FFP: ~30 minutes
– Platelets: ~15 minutes
– Cryoprecipitate: ~20 minutes
• During active transfusion:
– Blood products delivered per institutional algorithm
– TXA considered if bleeding onset < 3 hours
– Calcium supplementation recommended with ongoing transfusion
– PRBCs, plasma, and fluids warmed using approved devices
– Platelets and cryoprecipitate must not be warmed
Failure Behavior: • INDETERMINATE if transfusion status (administered vs anticipated) is not documented
• INDETERMINATE if Blood Bank involvement cannot be confirmed when transfusion is suspected
• NOT TRIGGERED only if no hemorrhage is present and no transfusion is administered or anticipated
Not Evaluated When: • Non-trauma admissions
• Trauma patients without hemorrhage and without transfusion requirement
Optional Missing-Data Hint: • Blood Bank documentation confirming transfusion or MTP activation
• Documentation stating transfusion was considered but deferred
Decision Flow (Authoritative Execution L: Does the patient meet Applicability Gate?

protocols.name: Hypothermia – Prevention and Treatment

Applicability Gate: • All trauma patients, regardless of injury severity, mechanism, or age
Required Data Elements: • Initial temperature measurement with timestamp
• Method of temperature measurement (core vs peripheral, if documented)
• Serial temperature measurements
• Documentation of warming measures applied
• Documentation of Trauma Surgeon notification when thresholds are met
• Documentation of repeat temperature at required intervals
Timing-Critical Elements: • Initial temperature must be obtained within 30 minutes of arrival to the treatment room
• Trauma room temperature maintained > 82°F
• Operating room temperature warmed to 85°F for emergent or >1-hour trauma cases
Failure Behavior: • INDETERMINATE if initial temperature is not documented
• INDETERMINATE if timing of temperature measurement is unclear
• INDETERMINATE if required rechecks or notifications are not documented
• NOT TRIGGERED only if patient is not a trauma patient
Not Evaluated When: • Non-trauma admissions
Optional Missing-Data Hint: • Explicit Trauma Surgeon notification when thresholds are met

PROTOCOL: Hypothermia – Prevention and Treatment

Protocol Class:
CLASS I — Triggerable Protocol

Applicability Gate:
• All trauma patients, regardless of injury severity, mechanism, or age

Trigger Criteria (Exact):
• Applicability Gate met

Required Data Elements:
• Initial temperature measurement with timestamp
• Method of temperature measurement (core vs peripheral, if documented)
• Serial temperature measurements
• Documentation of warming measures applied
• Documentation of Trauma Surgeon notification when thresholds are met
• Documentation of repeat temperature at required intervals

Authoritative Sources:
• Trauma H&P
• Physician notes
• Nursing documentation
• Anesthesia documentation (if operative)
• Vital sign records

Timing-Critical Elements:
• Initial temperature must be obtained within 30 minutes of arrival to the treatment room
• Trauma room temperature maintained > 82°F
• Operating room temperature warmed to 85°F for emergent or >1-hour trauma cases

Temperature-Driven Actions:
• If temperature < 96.8°F (36°C):
  – Initiate active rewarming immediately
  – Recheck temperature within 1 hour
  – If still < 96.8°F, notify Trauma Surgeon
• If temperature < 95.5°F:
  – Immediate Trauma Surgeon notification required

Failure Behavior:
• INDETERMINATE if initial temperature is not documented
• INDETERMINATE if timing of temperature measurement is unclear
• INDETERMINATE if required rechecks or notifications are not documented
• NOT TRIGGERED only if patient is not a trauma patient

Not Evaluated When:
• Non-trauma admissions

Optional Missing-Data Hint:
• Initial temperature with timestamp
• Serial temperature trend
• Documentation of warming interventions
• Explicit Trauma Surgeon notification when thresholds are met

protocols.name: Laboratory Studies Needed in Trauma Resuscitation

Applicability Gate: • Trauma patient presenting for initial trauma evaluation or resuscitation
• Includes Category I trauma activations, Category II activations, and trauma consultations managed under ED trauma workflow
Required Data Elements: • Trauma activation level (Category I vs Category II / consult)
• Anticipated operative intervention status
• Mechanism of injury (including MVC with suspected driver status)
• Patient age
• Mental status assessment
• Documentation of prior laboratory results from referring facility (if applicable)
Category I Trauma Patients: • Full trauma laboratory panel obtained immediately upon ED arrival (standing order)
Operative Trauma Patients: • Pre-operative laboratory studies obtained upon ED arrival when operative intervention is anticipated
Alcohol / Drug Screening Requirements: • Motor vehicle crash patient believed to be the driver:
– Blood alcohol level required unless result is already documented from referring facility
• Patient < 12 years of age when any of the following are present:
– History of drug and/or alcohol abuse
– Suspected driver of a motorized vehicle
– Significant change in level of consciousness or mental status
Category I Trauma Laboratory Panel Inclu: • Urinalysis with microscopic analysis (culture if indicated)
• Beta-HCG in females of child-bearing age (≤ 60 years)
Failure Behavior: • INDETERMINATE if trauma activation level is not documented
• INDETERMINATE if required laboratory studies are not obtained and no exclusion or prior results are documented
• INDETERMINATE if age, driver status, or mental status is unclear when screening applies
• NOT TRIGGERED only if patient is not a trauma patient
Not Evaluated When: • Non-trauma admissions
• Patients evaluated entirely outside the ED trauma workflow
Optional Missing-Data Hint: • EMS or history confirming driver status
• Referring facility laboratory results with timestamps
Decision Flow (Authoritative Execution L: Does the patient meet Applicability Gate?

protocols.name: Transfer of the Trauma Patient TO Deaconess Midtown

Applicability Condition: • Trauma patient initially evaluated at an outside facility
• Patient sustained a traumatic injury and was transferred to Deaconess Midtown Hospital for definitive trauma care
Execution Behavior: • It does NOT undergo trigger evaluation
• It must NOT render Triggered / Not Triggered / Indeterminate
Display Rules: • Display only when interfacility transfer to Deaconess Midtown has occurred
“Applicable — trauma patient transferred from outside facility”
Required Documentation Elements: • Confirmation that patient sustained a traumatic injury
• Documentation supporting need for transfer to Deaconess Midtown Hospital
• Level of care required during transport
Authoritative Sources: • Transfer forms and accompanying medical records
Timing Expectations: • Resuscitation performed prior to transfer within transferring facility capability
• Physician-to-physician communication completed prior to transfer
• Mode of transport determined before departure
• Transfer documentation accompanies patient at time of transfer
Omission Rule: • If patient was not transferred from an outside facility, this protocol is omitted silently
Prohibitions: • Do NOT render Triggered / Not Triggered / Indeterminate
• Do NOT log as missing when not applicable

protocols.name: Transfer of the Trauma Patient FROM Deaconess Midtown

Applicability Condition: • Trauma patient initially evaluated and/or admitted at Deaconess Midtown Hospital
• Patient sustained a traumatic injury and was transferred out to an equal or higher level trauma system
Execution Behavior: • It does NOT undergo trigger evaluation
• It must NOT render Triggered / Not Triggered / Indeterminate
Display Rules: • Display only when an interfacility transfer FROM Deaconess Midtown has occurred
“Applicable — trauma patient transferred to higher level of care”
Contextual Justifications (Documented Re: • Injury requires care not available at Deaconess Midtown Hospital
• Injuries deemed too complex by specialty surgeon
• Policy-driven transfers to equal or higher level trauma centers
System Constraints (Policy Enforcement): • Trauma patients must NOT be transferred to Deaconess Gateway Hospital unless ALL of the following are true:
– Patient no longer requires trauma admission
▪ Isolated orthopedic patient requiring specialized complex joint revision
– Trauma Medical Director and Trauma Orthopedic Medical Director have reviewed and discussed the transfer
Required Documentation Elements: • Confirmation of traumatic injury and mechanism
• Documentation that higher level of care was required
• Mode of transport and required level of care
• Transfer packet contents (labs, imaging, medical records)
Timing Expectations: • Decision to transfer from ED targeted within 2 hours of arrival (NTDB ED LOS definition)
• Physician-to-physician communication initiated promptly with goal of acceptance within 30 minutes
• Resuscitation and stabilization completed prior to transfer within Deaconess Midtown capability
• Transport initiated promptly once acceptance is secured
Omission Rule: • If no transfer FROM Deaconess Midtown occurs, this protocol is omitted silently
Prohibitions: • Do NOT render Triggered / Not Triggered / Indeterminate
• Do NOT log as missing when not applicable

protocols.name: Management and Triage of the Obstetrical Trauma Patient

Applicability Gate: • Trauma patient with confirmed pregnancy
• Estimated gestational age ≥ 18 weeks
At least one of the following: • Trauma activation involving a pregnant patient ≥ 18 weeks gestation
• Pregnant trauma patient ≥ 18 weeks gestation requiring fetal heart monitoring
• Pregnant trauma patient ≥ 18 weeks gestation requiring obstetrical team involvement during trauma evaluation
Required Data Elements: • Confirmation of pregnancy
• Estimated gestational age (≥ 18 weeks)
• Trauma activation status
• Documentation indicating need for fetal heart monitoring
• Documentation of obstetrical involvement or consultation
• Trauma Surgeon assessment and disposition decision
Timing-Critical Elements: • Immediate Call Center notification to page the OB ED physician when a trauma activation involves a pregnant patient ≥ 18 weeks gestation
• If fetal heart monitoring is required:
– Direct call to OB ED physician at 812-842-4149
– If no response within 5 minutes, call 812-842-4309
• OB ED physician responsibilities upon notification:
– Contact ED for clinical details
– Deploy Maternal and Neonatal Team (including Neonatal Transporter)
– Notify the patient’s Primary/Service OB Provider
• Trauma Surgeon remains primary decision maker until care is formally relinquished
• If no traumatic admission is required after Trauma Surgeon evaluation:
– Patient may be transferred to The Women’s Hospital (TWH) for obstetrical care
Failure Behavior: • INDETERMINATE if gestational age is not documented
• INDETERMINATE if need for fetal monitoring or obstetrical involvement cannot be determined
• NOT TRIGGERED if patient is pregnant but does not meet any trigger criteria
Not Evaluated When: • Non-pregnant patients
• Pregnant patients < 18 weeks gestation
• Non-trauma presentations
Decision Flow (Authoritative Execution L: Does the patient meet Applicability Gate?

protocols.name: Autopsy in the Trauma Patient

Applicability Gate: • Trauma patient death occurring while admitted under the trauma service
At least one of the following definition: Unexpected Death — Definition A (Early Unexplained Death):
All of the following: • Death occurs within the first 24 hours of admission, and
• No CT imaging was obtained prior to death, and
• No operative intervention occurred prior to death
• Death cannot be reasonably attributed to:
– The documented mechanism of injury, or
(i.e., cause of death is unclear or unexplained)
Required Data Elements: • Time of death
• Time interval from admission to death
• CT imaging status prior to death
• Operative intervention status prior to death
• Trauma Surgeon determination regarding expected vs unexpected death
• Vanderburgh County Coroner (VCC) disposition
• Organ donor status
• Family consent for autopsy when required
Timing-Critical Elements: • Upon identification of an unexpected trauma death:
– Trauma Surgeon advises RN that autopsy is requested
• RN must notify Vanderburgh County Coroner (VCC) per Hospital P&P 50-14S
• If patient is a potential organ donor:
– RN notifies VCC to coordinate with Indiana Donor Network (IDN)
• If VCC accepts the case:
– VCC directs autopsy process
• If VCC declines the case:
– RN informs VCC that Trauma Surgeon has requested autopsy
– RN notifies Trauma Surgeon of VCC declination
– Trauma Surgeon places autopsy order (verbal order acceptable)
– Family consent obtained per P&P 50-14S
– RN notifies VCC to proceed
– Trauma Services PI RN and Pathology are notified
• Autopsy performed by VCC
• Body released to mortuary upon completion
Failure Behavior: • INDETERMINATE if:
– Cause of death cannot be determined from available documentation, or
– Imaging or operative status prior to death cannot be confirmed, or
– Coroner disposition is not documented
• NOT TRIGGERED if death is expected and clearly attributable to documented injuries or comorbid conditions
Not Evaluated When: • Non-trauma patient deaths
• Trauma deaths clearly expected and attributable to documented injuries or comorbidities with no diagnostic uncertainty
Optional Missing-Data Hint: • Explicit Trauma Surgeon documentation stating death is unexpected
• Clear confirmation of CT and operative status prior to death
• Completed Consent for Autopsy form (when applicable)
Decision Flow (Authoritative Execution L: Does the patient meet Applicability Gate?

protocols.name: Rehabilitative Services and Discharge Planning for the Trauma Patient

Applicability Context: • Admitted trauma patient requiring inpatient care
• Patient has injuries, precautions, functional limitations, or social factors that may impact mobility, self-care, cognition, or discharge planning
Contextual Presence Rules: • This protocol applies when rehabilitation services and/or structured discharge planning are clinically indicated
• It does NOT represent a binary trigger event
• It must NOT be forced into Triggered / Not Triggered / Indeterminate logic
Execution Rules: • May appear in run protocols output ONLY when contextual applicability is explicitly documented
• Must render as:
“Applicable — contextual protocol”
• Must NEVER render Triggered / Not Triggered / Indeterminate
• Must be silently omitted if contextual applicability is not documented
Indicative Contexts (Non-Exhaustive): • Activity restrictions, spinal precautions, or hemodynamic instability
• Anticipated need for post-acute rehabilitation services
• Functional, cognitive, social, or environmental barriers to discharge
Authoritative Sources: • Rehabilitation assessment ideally within 48 hours of admission when indicated
• Therapy consults placed once activity is approved
• Social Work and Case Management engaged early for discharge planning
Prohibitions: • Do NOT evaluate as Triggered / Not Triggered
• Do NOT infer applicability in absence of documentation

Prohibitions:
• Do NOT evaluate as Triggered / Not Triggered

• Do NOT infer applicability in absence of documentation

protocols.name: Non-Accidental Trauma (NAT) in the Pediatric Patient

Applicability Gate: • Pediatric trauma patient ≤ 14 years of age
• Patient presents with suspected or possible non-accidental trauma (abuse or maltreatment)
History Indicators: • No history, inconsistent history, or changing history of injury
Physical Examination Findings: • Failure to thrive (abnormal weight, length, or head circumference)
• Any bruise in a non-ambulating child
• Any bruise in a non-exploratory location in children < 4 years
• Bruising in TEN region (torso, ears, neck)
• Patterned bruises, marks, or scars suggestive of inflicted injury
Radiographic / Imaging Findings: • Any fracture in a non-ambulating infant
• Subdural and/or subarachnoid hemorrhage in young children
• Particularly < 1 year of age without skull fracture
Required Data Elements: • Patient age
• Injury history and identity of historian
• Developmental age assessment
• Complete head-to-toe physical examination
• Imaging results (neuroimaging, skeletal survey, abdominal imaging as indicated)
• Laboratory studies (CBC, CMP, coagulation studies, etc.)
• Social Work consultation documentation
• CPS and law enforcement notification documentation when indicated
Timing-Critical Elements: • Immediate Social Work consultation upon suspicion of NAT
• CPS and law enforcement notification per policy
• Neuroimaging:
– Infants < 12 months: CT or MRI regardless of neurologic findings
– Children ≥ 12 months: CT if altered mental status or neurologic signs
• Skeletal survey:
– All children < 3 years
– Follow-up survey at ~2 weeks when indicated
• Ophthalmology evaluation obtained promptly when indicated
• Medical photography performed as early as possible
• Admission required for:
– Identified traumatic injury
– Ongoing NAT evaluation
– Safety concerns or CPS disagreement
Failure Behavior: • INDETERMINATE if history, examination, or imaging is incomplete
• INDETERMINATE if Social Work or CPS involvement is not documented
• NOT TRIGGERED if no suspicion indicators are identified after complete evaluation
Not Evaluated When: • Patient > 14 years of age
• Non-trauma presentations without concern for abuse or maltreatment
Optional Missing-Data Hint: • Full skin and musculoskeletal exam documentation
• Ophthalmology and photography reports when indicated
Decision Flow (Authoritative Execution L: Does the patient meet Applicability Gate?

protocols.raw_block:
PROTOCOL: Non-Accidental Trauma (NAT) in the Pediatric Patient

Protocol Class:
CLASS I — Triggerable Protocol

Applicability Gate:
• Pediatric trauma patient ≤ 14 years of age
• Patient presents with suspected or possible non-accidental trauma (abuse or maltreatment)

Trigger Criteria (Exact):
At least ONE of the following suspicion indicators is present:

History Indicators:
• No history, inconsistent history, or changing history of injury
• Unwitnessed injury
• Delay in seeking medical care
• Mechanism implausible for developmental age
• Prior ED visit for injury
• Domestic violence in the home
• Prematurity (< 37 weeks gestation)
• Low birth weight / IUGR
• Chronic medical conditions

Physical Examination Findings:
• Torn frenulum
• Failure to thrive (abnormal weight, length, or head circumference)
• Macrocephaly in infants (< 1 year)
• Any bruise in a non-ambulating child
• Any bruise in a non-exploratory location in children < 4 years
• Bruising in TEN region (torso, ears, neck)
• Patterned bruises, marks, or scars suggestive of inflicted injury

Radiographic / Imaging Findings:
• Metaphyseal fractures
• Rib fractures in infants
• Any fracture in a non-ambulating infant
• Undiagnosed healing fracture
• Subdural and/or subarachnoid hemorrhage in young children
• Particularly < 1 year of age without skull fracture

Required Data Elements:
• Patient age
• Injury history and identity of historian
• Developmental age assessment
• Complete head-to-toe physical examination
• Imaging results (neuroimaging, skeletal survey, abdominal imaging as indicated)
• Laboratory studies (CBC, CMP, coagulation studies, etc.)
• Social Work consultation documentation
• CPS and law enforcement notification documentation when indicated

Authoritative Sources:
• Trauma H&P
• Emergency Department physician notes
• Nursing documentation
• Imaging reports
• Laboratory data
• Social Work documentation
• Pediatric Intensivist documentation
• Ophthalmology documentation (if obtained)

Timing-Critical Elements:
• Immediate Social Work consultation upon suspicion of NAT
• CPS and law enforcement notification per policy
• Neuroimaging:
  – Infants < 12 months: CT or MRI regardless of neurologic findings
  – Children ≥ 12 months: CT if altered mental status or neurologic signs
• Skeletal survey:
  – All children < 3 years
  – Follow-up survey at ~2 weeks when indicated
• Ophthalmology evaluation obtained promptly when indicated
• Medical photography performed as early as possible
• Admission required for:
  – Identified traumatic injury
  – Ongoing NAT evaluation
  – Safety concerns or CPS disagreement

Failure Behavior:
• INDETERMINATE if history, examination, or imaging is incomplete
• INDETERMINATE if Social Work or CPS involvement is not documented
• NOT TRIGGERED if no suspicion indicators are identified after complete evaluation

Not Evaluated When:
• Patient > 14 years of age
• Non-trauma presentations without concern for abuse or maltreatment

Optional Missing-Data Hint:
• Complete developmental assessment
• Full skin and musculoskeletal exam documentation
• Skeletal survey results
• Social Work and CPS documentation
• Ophthalmology and photography reports when indicated

⸻

Decision Flow (Authoritative Execution Logic):

START

Does the patient meet Applicability Gate?
• NO → STOP (Not Evaluated)
• YES → Continue

Is required trigger data present?
• NO → INDETERMINATE
• YES → Continue

Does patient meet trigger criteria?
• YES → TRIGGERED
• NO → NOT TRIGGERED

protocols.name: Role of Trauma Services in the Admission or Consultation of Trauma Patients

Applicability Gate: • Injured patient presenting to Deaconess Midtown Hospital
• Patient requires a determination regarding Trauma Services admission versus Trauma Surgeon consultation
Trauma Services Admission Criteria: • Category I trauma activation requiring hospital admission
• Category II trauma activation requiring hospital admission
• Category I or II pediatric trauma activation (< 18 years of age) requiring admission
• Obstetrical trauma patient requiring Trauma Surgeon evaluation and inpatient management
Trauma Surgeon Consultation Criteria: • Injured patient requiring hospital admission for traumatic injury who does NOT meet Category I or II activation criteria
• Injured patient admitted to a non-Trauma service who requires Trauma Surgeon consultation
• Inpatient patient identified after admission to have an injury related to a traumatic mechanism
• Direct admission for traumatic injury meeting activation or consultation criteria
Required Data Elements: • Trauma activation level (Category I, Category II, or none)
• Patient age
• Pregnancy status when applicable
• Determination of Trauma Services admission versus consultation
• Admission service and Trauma Center admission type (when applicable)
• Documentation of Trauma Surgeon notification
• Documentation of Trauma Surgeon response time
• Physician-to-physician communication documentation for direct admissions
• Documentation of Trauma Services sign-off and transfer of care (when applicable)
Authoritative Sources: • EPIC consult order (IP Consult to Trauma Services)
Timing-Critical Elements: • Category I and Category II activations:
– Trauma Services admission when inpatient admission is required
• Trauma Surgeon consultation (non-activation):
– Phone call to ESA Call Center required
– EPIC consult order required
– ICU patient: Trauma Surgeon assessment within 1 hour of notification
– Non-ICU patient: Trauma Surgeon assessment within 6 hours of notification
• Direct admissions:
– Injuries < 24 hours old should be admitted through the Emergency Department
– If bypassing the ED, the Admitting Physician must consult Trauma Services and speak directly with the Trauma Surgeon
• Trauma Services sign-off:
– Trauma Surgeon must document transfer of care and identify receiving service
– Order placed if receiving service is not already involved
Failure Behavior: • INDETERMINATE if trauma activation level is not documented
• INDETERMINATE if admission service or consultation timing is unclear
• INDETERMINATE if Trauma Surgeon notification or response is not documented
• NOT TRIGGERED if no traumatic injury is identified
Not Evaluated When: • Non-trauma admissions
• Medical patients without injury related to a traumatic mechanism
Optional Missing-Data Hint: • EPIC Trauma Services consult order with timestamp
• Trauma Surgeon progress note documenting admission decision or sign-off
Decision Flow (Authoritative Execution L: Does the patient meet Applicability Gate?

protocols.name: Management of Transmediastinal Gunshot Wounds

Applicability Gate: • Trauma patient with penetrating gunshot wound
• Trajectory suggests possible transmediastinal involvement (heart, great vessels, pulmonary hilar structures, tracheobronchial tree, or esophagus)
Cardiac Arrest: • Cardiac arrest with witnessed signs of life in the prehospital phase or upon arrival
Hemodynamic Instability: • Hypotension after injury with concern for mediastinal involvement
Hemodynamically Stable With Suspected Tr: • Presence of vital signs with suspected transmediastinal trajectory based on entry/exit wounds or imaging
Required Data Elements: • Mechanism confirming gunshot wound
• Entry and exit wound locations (if present)
• Determination of suspected transmediastinal trajectory
• Presence or absence of cardiac arrest
• Presence or absence of witnessed signs of life
• Hemodynamic status (SBP, heart rate)
• Chest imaging results (portable chest x-ray; CT chest with contrast when stable)
• Findings suggesting pneumothorax, hemothorax, mediastinal widening, pericardial effusion, or pulse differential
• Documentation of esophageal imaging when non-operative management is pursued
Authoritative Sources: • Imaging reports (chest x-ray, CT chest with contrast)
Timing-Critical Elements: • Cardiac arrest with witnessed signs of life:
– Immediate emergent thoracotomy
– Consider right-sided thoracotomy for right-sided entry without exit; clamshell extension permitted
• Hemodynamic instability:
– Immediate ATLS-directed resuscitation
– Large-bore IV access (one above and one below the diaphragm)
– Chest tube placement on side of entry wound
– Consider tension pneumothorax and pericardial tamponade
– Activate Massive Transfusion Protocol (MTP) and administer TXA as appropriate
• Hemodynamically stable patients:
– Rapid diagnostic evaluation including chest x-ray
– CT chest with contrast when stable
– If mediastinal widening, supramediastinal enlargement, or radial pulse differential present → consider angiography
– Non-operatively managed patients require esophageal imaging (e.g., water-soluble swallow study)
• All non-operatively managed patients:
– Admission required with follow-up imaging
Failure Behavior: • INDETERMINATE if trajectory cannot be determined
• INDETERMINATE if witnessed signs-of-life status is unclear in cardiac arrest
• INDETERMINATE if hemodynamic status is not documented
• NOT TRIGGERED if gunshot wound does not suggest mediastinal traversal
Not Evaluated When: • Penetrating injuries without mediastinal trajectory
• Non-gunshot penetrating mechanisms managed under other protocols
Optional Missing-Data Hint: • Clear documentation of entry and exit wounds
• EMS documentation of signs of life
• Esophageal imaging results when managed non-operatively
Decision Flow (Authoritative Execution L: Does the patient meet Applicability Gate?
